Up to fol. 287 (Ezekiel) beginnings of Books and Prefaces have painted floriated initials (sometimes with borders) in blue, pink, orange-brown, and yellow, generally on pink grounds, sometimes incorporating monsters (fols. 1r, 107v), birds (fol. 84r, 95v, 183r), monsters’ heads (fols. 22v, 47v, 93v, 162v, 170v, 174r, 192v); there is another painted initial on fol. 440r; other initials are red and blue with fine pen flourishes in the same colours, or red flourished in blue or blue in red, often with elaborate bicoloured trails of penwork in the margins. ( iii. 455) Pächt and Alexander

Initials to books blue and red flourished in red and blue, the first (fol. 7) with elaborate flourishes forming borders in the upper and left margins; smaller initials blue flourished in red or red in blue.
Initials in red and blue (smaller ones red or blue), with elaborate pen flourishes in red, blue, and mauve extending into the upper and lower margins.

Larger initials (fol. 1, 13v, 43, 69, 100v, 148v, 173v, 215v) in blue and red with fine flourishing in red and blue; the initial on fol. 1 includes a bird and two monsters, smaller initials red flourished in blue or blue in red. ( iii. 606) Pächt and Alexander

One painted initial survives at the beginning of book III (fol. 147): it is in pink, on a blue and pink ground with some geometrical decoration in straps of pink and decorated with spots of gold; on fols. 2r, 4v, 7v, 9v and 12r, initials in blue and red flourished in red and blue, other initials red flourished in blue or blue in red penwork.
Initials in blue flourished in red or red in violet.
Initial on fol. 1r in red and blue joined to frame border of penwork with alternating bands of red and blue and projecting red water-lily-shaped flower heads.
Rubrics and initials omitted.

Fol. 1 initial in blue and red on gold ground, infilled with interlacing foliage, and joined to border framing the text formed of panels in the same colours, decorated in white, and divided by foliage or interlace on gold grounds and with sprays of leaves extending into outer margins; fols. 57r, 67r, 92r, similar initals with bar borders, similarly decorated, framing the text; smaller initials gold on decorated red and blue grounds with small sprays of leaves. ( iii. 856, pl. LXXXI) Pächt and Alexander
Initials in red and green, with some yellow wash, blue is used in addition on fol. 2, 14v, 108v. Headings mostly in red only, but occasionally in red and green. ( iii. 223) Pächt and Alexander

Fol. 1, on gold ground, initial in blue filled with sprouting interlacing foliage in blue, red, and orange, all decorated in white, joined to a bar border on three sides with clusters and sprays of foliage in the same colours. There are some touches of pale green. Similar initials and border on fols. 3r, 34v, 53v, 74v, 99r, 142r, 159v. Other initals in blue, skilfully flourished in red. ( iii. 864) Pächt and Alexander
Plain red or blue initials.

Initial on fol. 1r in blue on brownish-red ground, framed in gold, infilled with leaves in the same colours on a gold ground, and joined to a bar border on three sides, ending in sprays of spiky foliage on the fourth side. The colours are decorated in white. Other initials are blue flourished in red. ( iii. 697) Pächt and Alexander
Blue initials flourished in red.
Miniatures crudely drawn in ink and coloured in red, blue and green.

Two main hands: and . Large painted foliate initials in on fols. 39r, 54v, 68r, 82v, 102r, 118v, 136v, generally basically in blue (fol 68r in pink), on gold backgrounds, with further decoration in orange, pink, green, and red, with bar borders in gold and colours extending into the upper and lower margins and ending in clusters of leaves. Other initials to Psalms in are in gold on backgrounds of pink and blue, or green, with sprays of coloured leaves, initials to verses are alternately blue flourished in red, or red in purple; has painted initials on fols. 1r, 188v, 197r, 200r, in gold on backgrounds of pink and blue, decorated in white, with sprays of tiny gold or coloured leaves sprouting from outer corners. Other initials in are mostly blue flourished in red; in the calendar some are gold flourished in purple. ( iii. 1045) a b a a b b Pächt and Alexander

On fols. 1r, 8v, 26v, 65r, painted foliate initials in pink, blue, green, and mauve on gold backgrounds, joined to gold bar borders, with coloured foliate decoration and sprays of tiny leaves, which frame the text. Other initials in blue flourished in red. ( iii. 1046) Pächt and Alexander

On fol. 8r (much worn) painted foliate initial in colours (blue, orange, pink, green) on gold background, joined to gold bar border, with coloured foliate decoration, which frames the text. Similar initials with smaller borders on fols. 41v, 52v, 59v, 72v, 80v. Smaller painted initials, similar or in gold on coloured backgrounds with sprays of coloured leaves and rayed gold studs on fols. 22r, 28r, 66r, etc. Other initials in blue flourished in red. ( iii. 1107) Pächt and Alexander
2-line blue initials with red penwork at the beginnings of prologues and chapters.
Rubrics in red ink.
4-line gold initials (8-line initials ‘I’) on blue and pink background at the beginnings of books; the first with a spray of penwork and gold leaves and disks.
2- to 3-line blue initials with red penwork at the beginnings of prologues and chapters.
2- to 5-line ‘puzzle’ initials in red and blue, and red and blue penwork borders (right margin) at the beginnings of epistles.

Main initials in gold on grounds of red and blue, decorated with foliage and with small borders consisting of sprays of foliage; other large initials in blue flourished in red; small initials in blue or red flourished in red or violet. ( iii. 1019) Pächt and Alexander
In the middle of the page, in a roundel formed of concentric circles of blue, gold, and red, a miniature of Adam and Eve being tempted by the serpent.
There is also a smaller initial in gold on a plum red and blue ground.
Other initials are gold flourished in brown or blue in red.
On fol. 1v is an initial in plum red and blue on a gold ground infilled with scrolled acanthus leaves and joined to borders of foliage along the top and left sides.

Fol. 1 pink initial on gold ground joined to bar border framing the text with acanthus leaves in pink, blue, orange, and green and pen scrolling with small gold and green flowers and leaves, rubbed. Other initials gold on decorated blue and pink grounds with sprays of pen scrolling and small gold and green flowers and leaves. ( iii. 1066) Pächt and Alexander
Initials in first, second and third quires blue flourished in red, others plain red. Diagrams, some representational. ( iii. 1165) Pächt and Alexander

Crude initials in English translation of William Reed’s canons (pp. 25–55) in colours (blue, orange, green, mauve) on yellow grounds, on p. 25 infilled with a flower, on p. 26 accompanied by a bar border and foliage, and on p. 43 by an unfinished border of foliage and flowers sketched in ink; in other items initials either plain red, or omitted. ( iii. 1127) Pächt and Alexander
Initials blue flourished in red.

On fols. 7r, 122r, large painted initials in blue and pink on gold infilled with foliage, joined to bar borders decorated with acanthus leaves and hairline ink scrolling with painted daisies and other flowers, and small gold leaves and discs, extending into all the margins on fol. 122r, three sides only on fol. 7r. On fol. 123r, a large gold initial with pink and blue background, hairline scrolling, flowers, and gold leaves. Some similar smaller initials; a few others in gold flourished in red and blue; the rest are red or blue flourished in blue or red. ( i. 677) Pächt and Alexander
The ink initial on fol. 1r is in the form of a fish. I
The initials are flourished with penwork in Bruges style; that on fol. 1r is red and blue flourished in blue and red, the rest are red with blue or blue with red.

Decorated red initials on fol. 101, 105v, 121.

Spaces left for headings, not filled in; elaborate vinescroll type initials drawn in red and brown ink on fol. 11v (with monster) and fol. 30; compare an initial, done at Admont, from MS. Admont 83 in P. Buberl, (Beschr. Verzeichnis der ilium. Hss. in Oesterreich iv), Leipzig, 1911, p. 83, fig. 85. Decorated red initials on fol. 1, iv, 14v. Die Mum. Hss. in Steiermark, I. There are a number of early marginal scribbles, many of them done with a stylus.

The MS. has a series of fifty-one fine initials, mostly of the vinescroll type, akin in style to those of the 12th-cent. Salzburg school. They are outlined in mauve ink, except for the last four, which are in brown ink, and occasionally shaded in green, with solid backgrounds of blue, green, and pink.
Titles in red capitals.

The following have figures: fol. 29v, a naked boy, bird and monster heads; fol. 55v, a man, bird and dog; fol. 67, naked boy and monster; fol. 77v, man and monster; fol. 79, man and monster; fol. 88v, naked man and bear; fol. 91, naked man; fol. 93v, man and monster; fol. 97v, man; fol. 99v, young man standing holding two monsters; fol. 102v, bearded man seated between two monsters; fol. 103v, man and monster; fol. 106v, naked green man. Others have animals only: birds , monsters or monster heads , a bear . i. 73, pl. VI, . Pächt and Alexander
The MS. has a series of fine initials, mostly of the vinescroll type, drawn mainly in red but with further details in lilac or light-brown ink, sometimes with parts washed in yellow or green.

Some of the initials have zoomorphic features: birds (fols. 1, 1v, 6v, 44v, 75, 192, 209v), monsters (fols. 34, 44v, 55, 97v) and a hare ; others have figures: the risen Christ , St. John the Baptist (fols. 78v, 95: freestanding figures); heads: fol. 70r, 73r, 86r (Christ and St. Mary Magdalene), 87v (St. James), in (St. Cecilia), 113v (St. Andrew), 117 (St. Thomas), 135v (a monk). On fol. 168 is a figure of a monk, possibly intended to be Honorius himself. The style of the initials is close to the Salzburg school of the second half of the 12th cent., and the style of drawing of the figures and faces is similar to that in the codex from Lambach, now MS. Berlin theol. lat. qu. 140 (see Swarzenski, 1913, pp. 154–5 and Abb. 413–21) and that in the St. Augustine from Lambach (Sotheby sale, 12 Nov. 1929, lot 389, with plates) and the copy of Honorius on the Song of Songs, now Baltimore, Walters Art Gallery MS. W. 29 (ex-Lambach xciv, identified by H. Menhaxdt, , in 89 (1958–9), 60), illustrated in J. Rosenthal, 90), 1928, Taf. viii (no. 144), and Walters Art Gallery Exhibition Catalogue, Baltimore 1949, pl. xviil (no. 27). According to Swarzenski, the use of red and violet together in the pen drawing, with occasional use of brown ink, and of yellow wash, are characteristics of MSS. from Lambach (op. cit., p. 155). Pächt–Alexander 1, no. 80, pl. vii . Williram Salzburger Malerei, Der Nachlass des H. A. Zeitschrift für deutsches Altertum und Literatur Bibi. Med. Aevi MSS. H Kat. Illuminated Books of the M. Ages and Renaissance,

Vinescroll type initial in red and violet ink on fol. 9r, and small initial in blue and red on fol. 113v; decorated red initials on fols. 1r, 8v, 41r, 80v, 98v, 127v, 145v. ( i. 93) Pächt and Alexander

Added, a framed pen drawing of St. Clare, labelled and dated 1472, fol. i verso. She is dressed as an abbess and holds a monstrance in her right hand and a book and pastoral staff in her left hand. She is accompanied by the verses: . Sente Claren Dit isz sente Claren de sal unsz bewaren vur Tufels list und varen ytzt und in allen J aren
Decorated initials.

Pen drawings: fol. 1r, King Solomon; fol. 13v, Christ preaching (?); fol. 121v, head of Christ, and a monster; fol. 144r, a bishop, in the border are a monster and a bird. On fols. 56v-57r similar drawings have been coloured, chiefly in deep blue, with pale blue, orange, green, and violet: fol. 56v, miniature of King Solomon on his throne.
fol. 57r, initial with a bishop.

Lesser initials are red and blue flourished in the same colours, or blue flourished in red, or red in blue.
Larger initials are blue and red with foliate decoration painted in green, brown, and yellow on a red ground.

On fol. 37 (Lib. Num., cap. II) is a circular diagram with inscriptions in the hand of gloss a, illustrating the arrangement of the camps of the twelve tribes of Israel around the tabernacle; cf. similar diagram in Peter of Poitier's Compendium historiae, e.g. in MSS. Lyell 71, fol. 20; Fairfax 13, 13th cent., fol. 2v, etc. On fol. 57 a genealogy, linked to gloss a, appears to have been erased to make way for gloss b; other diagrams or drawings have been erased on fol. 67v, 68, 135. On fol. 7 another glossator, slightly later than a, has drawn diagrams of the interior arrangement of Noah's ark 'secundum Augustinum', and 'secundum alios'. A drawing of a peacock on fol. 10 may be by the same hand. ( ii. 67) Pächt and Alexander

There is a series of marginal pen drawings, sometimes with red touches, most of which appear to have been done by the first glossator (a) or at about the same time as gloss a, to which they are often joined, and certainly before gloss b, which is sometimes written over them (e.g. fol. 47, 68, 86v). The drawings are mostly of fantastic monsters, but there are also lions (fol. 32v, 47, 86v), birds (fol. 32v, 66v (double-headed), 88v, 118v), fish (fol. 68, 101) and heads (e.g. a king, fol. 44) and they sometimes consist partly of acanthus scrolling (fol. 4, 15v, 67v). Noteworthy are: (fol. 34v–35) large monsters; (fol. 61) head with three faces; (fol. 103) woman holding up a flaming torch; (fol. 107v) front part of a bull, with head turned full-face.
Blue and red initials with pen flourishes, sometimes partly formed of birds (fol. 1, 2).

On fols. 3r, 4v, 30r, 34r, 35r, 41r, 49r, painted initials on gold grounds, in orange red, violet, pale blue, and pink, shaded and diapered, with scrolled foliage, and framed in dark blue, or pink (fol. 4v only).

The headings and first line of the first poem are written in large capitals in alternate lines of gold and blue. There are no initials for the later poems, but their headings are written in violet or red; a black bear, symbolizing the Orsini, has been painted at the beginning of several of the poems. Probably the presentation copy and written by himself. ( ii. 374) Michele Pächt and Alexander

On fols. 1r, 2v, 23r, 66v, faceted initials in blue, green, or plum on rectangular backgrounds with concave sides and bevelled corners in the same colours; smaller initials plain red or blue. In the lower margin of fol. 1r on a delicately shaded blue background two standing putti support the Barbo arms, with a cross and cardinal’s hat above. Probably the dedication copy presented to , by Barozzi whilst bishop of Belluno, 1471–1487. ( ii. 560, pl. LII) Cardinal Marco Barbo, patriarch of Aquileia Pächt and Alexander

Fol. 1r, interlacing ink-drawn initial framed in red with background in pale yellow and red inside and blue outside. First words of the text written in large capitals in alternating lines of red and blue. On fol. 13r, the heading is in large rustic capitals, with alternate words in red and brown, and the initial is in red and blue, with the first four words in large red and blue capitals. Smaller initials on fols. 1v-7v are in gold, outlined in red. Later initials are in red (mostly) or brown, occasionally with some decoration in ink (or blue), sometimes accompanied by yellow wash. ( i. 876, pl. LXV) Pächt and Alexander

Initials red or blue with pen flourishes in violet or green. On fol. 1r a crude initial in silver and gold and an unfinished border of foliage, added 16th-17th century, drawn in ink, washed in yellow, and partly coloured red. ( i. 889) Pächt and Alexander

Decorated initials and border on fol. 1r. Decorated initials, initials with penwork, simple red and blue initials. ( i. 163, pl. XII) Pächt and Alexander

On fol. 1 the first initial is in blue and gold infilled with flowers and foliage drawn in red and purple ink, with a background in green and blue. A gold bar border, ending in a blue floral spray and with purple pen decoration touched in green and blue, extends in the left-hand border. The second initial is in blue and red flourished in purple and red with a red bar border ending in an elaborate scrolling of flowers in red and blue. On fol. 87 is a painted initial in blue, scrolled in white and outlined in orange and red-brown, infilled with a spray of flowers in yellow and white on a divided orange and deep-red ground.

Other large initials are in red and blue, flourished in red and blue, or purple, sometimes with red bar borders. The initial on fol. 102v is infilled with flowers drawn in pen, partly washed in yellow and outlined in green. Smaller initials are in red and blue. Paragraph marks, also in red or blue, are often extended into the margins to form grotesques, etc.: e.g. fol. 28v, 39v, 40v, 74v, no, 113 and on fol. 59 and 56v flowers have been drawn independently. column8: full border Winged putti and birds against background of interlaced white stems with folliage and flowers; gold disks. Seven panels with miniatures: Love as blindfold winged putto with bow and arrow; two panels with half-figues of a young man and a woman in conversation or embracing; profile head of the author with laurel wreath; a lion; a stag; a red lily of Florence. At the bottom of the page two winged putti support a diamond ring (a Medici emblem) with a coat of arms (azure a castle argent surmounting three mounts or).

2- to 3-line gold initials with floral, zoomorphic and anthropomorphic designs, in rectangular frames, on red, blue and green background with Medici emblems, accompanied by similarly decorated one-sides borders with Medici emblems (gemmed ring; double yoke, sometimes surmounted by N; three ostrich feathers; lion masks; staff raguly; silver scroll sometimes with lettering ‘semper’) on white (usually with a pattern of silver dots), or red and blue background at the beginning of psalms 11 (fol. 14v), 21 (fol. 26r), 36 (fol. 45v), 46 (fol. 61r), 56 (fol. 73v), 66 (fol. 84v), 76 (fol. 100v), 86 (fol. 115v), 96 (fol. 128v), 111 (fol. 151r), 121 (fol. 169r), 131 (fol. 174v), 141 (fol. 184v), the beginning of weekly canticles (fol. 194r) and prayers before mass (fol. 211v). 3-line initial, without a border, is at the start of the daily canticles (fol. 205r).

4-line gold Beatus-initial (fol. 4r), decorated with floral, zoomorphic and anthropomorphic designs, on blue background in a rectangular frame, infilled with nimbed David (?), kneeling in prayer in a landscape. Rectangular border with gold floral, zoomorphic and anthropomorphic designs, including beasts, birds, grotesques, masks and human figures on red, green and blue background. Eight medallions, seven framed by gemmed rings and one, in the lower margin, supported by two putti. Two of the medallions contain Medici arms, and six Medici emblems (three ostrich feathers with ‘semper’ written on a white scroll, and double yoke, surmounted by N, with ‘svave’ written on a white scroll).
Borders: see above.

miniatures (coloured drawings) Venus, standing in water, surrounded by flowers and doves. Cupid with bow and arrow. Apollo. Vulcan with hammer. Mercury with goat’s head, winged feet and helmet, holding a wand with a snake twined around it, playing pipe. Cock. Argus asleep.
miniatures (coloured drawings) Juno, with head covered with clouds, supported by peacocks; rainbow. Cybele in a chariot pulled by lions; three cocks.
miniatures (coloured drawings) Mars in a carriage; wolf. Apollo and muses, standing around a laurel tree; raven; three-headed dragon. Python pierced with spear.
miniatures (coloured drawings) Diana, hunting with bow and arrow, surrounded by attendants. Minerva in armour, with spear and shield with Medusa’s head. Rainbow, cock, laurel tree, owl.

Red ink is used lavishly, for running heads, chapter headings (in the text or the margin), proper names, initials, and decoration, and initials are often touched in red. Wilde wrote continuously, using brown or red ink as necessary, for example, the ‘auctoritas’ for each stanza of Nos. 8 and 20 is written in red, at the same time as the rest of the text. Running heads are provided for the first few folios of each book of No. 1, and throughout Nos. 12 and 30. Proper names are frequently given capital initials.
miniatures (coloured drawings) Venus, embracing Mars, confronted by Vulcan with hammer and four . Hercules with staff and lion’s head. Asclepius with serpent-entwined staff. dij etherei

miniatures (coloured drawings) Saturn, devouring his son, castrated by Jupiter, surrounded by other gods and goddesses. Jupiter, seated on the throne, striking giants with lightning. Ganymede and eagle.

Fine historiated initial with partial border. fol. 1r: initial U, a ram and a bull underneath a tree: the ram is a rebus for Ramsey and the bull alludes to the story of the abbey's foundation where a bull will strike the ground with its right foot (Lucy Freeman Sandler, 'The Historical Miniatures of the Fourteenth-Century Ramsey Psalter', 111, No. 799 (Oct., 1969), 605-611 at 606). Decoration is in red only (with some gaps).
Initials for each line set on outer line (as in Part I). Punctuation at margin only, as in Part I. The initials are in red, blue, and green.

Initials of each line are placed in the outer column; punctuation is after the final letter of each line. Some pages are heavily glossed and annotated in a contemporary hand. Initials for poems and sections in red only.

Initials for each line of verse are set on the outer line of the left-hand double column. Each line has a final punctum at the right-hand edge of the writing frame; each poem concludes with a punctus versus. Initials for poems in red; after p. 14 blue initials occur; in pp. 67–98 blue and red alternate, inconsistently.

Initial letters of poems (and sections within poems) in red, occasionally blue, occasionally red with blue work (but the blue ink has faded); in Part IV (pp. 125–142), red, green, and blue. Cue letters are visible in Parts II-IV, but not in Part I.

Initials to each line set within column, as in Part II. Punctuation is placed not only after the final letter of each verse line (as in Part II) but also at the right-hand margin, as in Part I, except that here a punctus versus is used for each line.
Initials to each line are set within the left-hand column. The punctuation comes after the final letter of each verse line (i.e., not at the margin).

Pages left blank for large illuminated initials (?) at liturgical divisions: psalms 26 (?) (leaf cut out after fol. 13), 38 (fol. 22v), 51 (fol. 30v), 52 (fol. 31v), 68 (fol. 40v), 80 (fol. 51r), 97 (fol. 61r), 101 (fol. 63r) and 109 (?) (leaf cut out after fol. 71). The first verses of psalms are also omitted. The initials were pasted on leaves left blank and later removed. Blank pages have discoloration, traces of glue and bleed-through left by the initials, including green borders and traces of text (e.g. ‘AS’ on fol. 22v, the last letters of ‘meas’); ‘VS’ on fol. 40v (the last letters of ‘deus’)).
1-line plain, alternating red and blue initials at the beginnings of verses and periods.

Border decoration on fol. 1r is in a different style from the rest of the psalter.Master of the Egerton Genesis
column8: (full border) Jesse Tree (reclining Jesse; 12 panels, framed with vines, bearing leaves and grapes, containing twelve crowned figures, including Solomon with a model of the Temple).

MS. 44949) (Millar, 1938; Pächt, 1943) and the Crucifixion and Christ in Majesty miniatures in the Fitzwarin Psalter (Paris, Bibliothèque nationale MS. lat. 765) (Wormald, 1943). column8: Calendar: Pink and blue KL monograms on gold background and borders made of pink, blue and gold bars, decorated with sprays of leaves (both side-margins in January and left margin only in other months). The borders incorporate the Signs of the Zodiac, and a Labour of the Month for January: January: man sitting on a stool, stirring the contents of a cauldron; hybrid Aquarius February: Pisces (man holding two fish) March: Aries April: Taurus May: Gemini (two profile heads and two arms supporting a shield, party per pale, sable and argent) June: Cancer July: Leo August: Virgo September: Libra (man holding scales) October: Scorpio emerging from a bishop’s mitre November: Capricorn December: Sagittarius

Scrolls with lettering: ‘Non est deus’ (Fool); ‘Tu mentiris aperte’ (cleric); ‘Ecce dicit incipiens’ (God).

fol. 19r, initial S, Pentecost (dove descends on the Virgin Mary and apostles; defaced). Dragon's body forms the descender of the letter and border in the lower margin.
fol. 1r, initial R, Resurrection (Christ holding staff with cross, steps out of the tomb (defaced); soldiers asleep on the ground); grotesques.
fol. 22r, initial B, Christ enthroned (rubbed). Hybrid figure (dragon's body and human half-figure holding a club) forms the descender of the letter and border in the lower margin.
Good borders.
fol. 16v, initial U, Apostles watching the Ascension of Christ (badly rubbed). Dragon's body and crowned half-figure, playing harp (King David (?)), form the descender of the letter.
Good initials.
Good borders.

1-line plain alternating red and blue initials at the beginnings of verses.
Rubrics in red ink.

The Beatus-initial is cut out, but there is a full border on fol. 1r, made of gold, blue and pink bars, filigree scrolls, flowers, foliage and gold discs. There is a similar border and a 5-line blue initial on gold background, infilled with flowers, at the beginning of psalm 109 (fol. 106r).
2-line gold initials on blue or pink background, decorated with white geometric and arabesque designs, at the beginnings of psalms, canticles, litany and prayers.

5-line gold initials on blue or pink background, decorated with white floral designs, and borders in the outer margins, made of filigree scrolls, flowers, foliage and gold discs at liturgical divisions, at the beginnings of psalms 26 (fol. 21r), 38 (fol. 33v), 51 (fol. 45v), 52 (fol. 46r), 68 (fol. 58v), 80 (fol. 74v) and 97 (fol. 89r).
Miniatures.
Borders.

column7: iii. 972, pl. XCI. Holly James-Maddocks distinguishes five artists: A (responsible for most borders, fols. 7r, 14r, 24r, 31r, 34r, 50r, 55r, 106r, 116r, 138r, 162r, and possibly the majority of initials), B (the border artist of Huntington HM 932, borders on fols. 20r, 26r, 28r, 43r, 73r, 95v, 126r, 150v); C (identified as , spray initials on fols. 32r-39r); D (border, fol. 87v), E (borders, fols. 88v, 95r) (H. James-Maddocks, 'The peripatetic activity of Thomas Tresswell, London Stationer (fl. 1440-1470)', in , ed. Stella Panayotova and Paola Ricciardi (Harvey Miller Publishers, 2017), pp. 109-123). Pächt and AlexanderThomas TresswellManuscripts in the Making: Art & Science. Volume One
column8: 3-line initials on gold backgrounds and three-quarter borders, decorated with foliage, flowers and gold discs, at the beginnings of psalms 16 (fol. 87v), 17 (fol. 88v) and 25 (fol. 95r). Decoration on fol. 87v is in a different style from the rest of the manuscript, doubtless by the artist of the missing Beatus-initial, with which fol. 87 was originally conjoint.

(fol. 1r) A historiated initial, seven lines high, containing four figures (two male, two female) in the foreground of a green field with a figure pointing with a golden speer from above. Behind the figures is the walls of a city. One of the figures is labelled ‘Troylus’ and another ‘Cr[ ]’ in gold.

Decorated initials appear at the beginning of Books III-V of Troilus and Criseyde, with shades of blue wash on a gilt background infilled with florals. More simplistic initials appear at the beginning of five texts, once within Troilus and Criseyde, and at the beginning of each legend in The Legend of Good Women. These are characterised by a gilded and quartered design in purple and blue.
Ascenders are occasionally decorated, perhaps by a later hand. The arms of Henry, 3rd Lord Sinclair appear on fol. 118v.

There are 21 demi-vinets (or bar-borders) across the manuscript which include penwork tracery, gold studding, blue acanthus leaves, strawberries, and floral shapes in blue and gold. The majority include birds. The demi-vinets mark significant points of division between texts and within Troilus and Criseyde: fols. 1v, 41v, 67r, 91v, 111v, 120v, 132r, 134r, 137v, 138v, 152v, 192r, 111r, 163r, 166r, 172v, 177r, 180r, 185r, and 187v.

(Fair-Welcome is wrongly depicted as a young girl, possibly the heroine herself, instead of a young 'bachelier'. Jean de Meung from his treatment of the Lover’s gift also appears unmindful of this fact, though the Old-Woman continues to address Fair-Welcome as 'Beaus fiz').

column8: (fol. 23v) As the Lover stands disconsolate Reason descends from her tower to address him. Youthful folly, she claims, has brought him to this pass. Her advice is that he should leave the service of Love. To which the Lover replies that he is Love’s man and would rather die than betray his Lord. Reason, realizing that what she advises is unacceptable departs (line 2971).

Fol. 1 opens with a tree of Jesse from which grows four roundels, on a gold base, with green leaves, but with the roundels having figures in red and white on a blue background, hashed with white and red. Each book opens with an eleven-line historiated initial, with a thin border often running the height of the written space. The palette is dominated by pink and blue, with a little use of gold, red and green. In each case, the depiction is of the author, with each evangelist having his symbol. There are occasional marginal grotesques and lions (e.g. fol. 68v); other grotesques float in the margin near chapter openings. Scot McKendrick attributed the decoration to the Cholet Master. Each chapter has a three-line initial in the same palette. Running headers in majuscules, alternating red and blue, as do chapter numbers. On the artist, see M. A. Stones, ‘Les manuscrits du cardinal Jean Cholet et l'enluminure beauvaisienne vers la fin du XIIIème siècle’ in (Beauvais, 2001), pp. 239-66. See also her discussion of Padua, Biblioteca Capitolare, MSS D 34 and C 47 in , i/2, pp. 54-57 and ii/2, fig. 110–115. L'Art gothique dans l'Oise et ses environs: Architecture civile et religieuse, peinture murale, sculpture et arts précieux, etc. …; Colloque international organisé à Beauvais les 10 et 11 octobre 1998 par le G.E.M.O.B. (Groupe d’Etude des Monuments et Oeuvres d'Art de l'Oise et du Beauvais) Gothic Manuscripts

column7: One miniature and 16 painted initials, using the same colors and apparently all done by the same artist or workshop that also painted the initial in Vienna, Museum für angewandte Kunst–Barockbibliothek, S 25, fol. 1r.
column8: Miniature on fol. 4v, depicting four angels holding a monstrance containing a host turned into the Christ child; 77 × 105 mm; gilded frame; inscriptions in rubricated Textura: Ave rex noster fili David redemptorand Ecce panis Angelorum sanctis cibus; background showing floral elements and a star filled sky (green, red, violet, yellow, black, blue, brown, gold, gilding).

column7: One miniature and 16 painted initials, using the same colors and apparently all done by the same artist or workshop that also painted the initial in Vienna, Museum für angewandte Kunst–Barockbibliothek, S 25, fol. 1r.
column8: 16 elaborated and skillfully painted initials, most of them with gilded elements: fol. 5r: painted E-initial, 24 × 25 mm (green, blue, white, black, yellow, floral tendrils in brown ink), historiated E-initial with gilded elements, 43 × 45 mm, depicting violet flower, probably Myosotis (green, red, violet, white, black, yellow, blue, floral tendrils in brown ink, two painted floral extensions in watercolor) and floral decoration on the lower margin (clover, ink drawing colorized in green, yellow, violet and white); fol. 46r: historiated O-initial, depicting male portrait (red and violet ink, floral tendrils in brown ink) and floral decoration on the lower margin (carnation, ink drawing colorized in green, red and yellow); fol. 72r: painted O-initial with gilded elements, 25 × 34 mm (blue, black, yellow, gilding, floral tendrils in brown ink); fol. 80v: painted and historiated O-initial with gilded elements, 30 × 33 mm, depicting violet flowers, probably Myosotis (white, green, red, violet, black, yellow, gilding) and floral decoration on the lower margin (strawberry plant, ink drawing colorized in green, red and yellow); fol. 90v: E-initial with gilded elements, 31 × 35 mm (black, gilding, floral tendrils in brown ink); fol. 114v: painted and historiated O-initial with gilded elements, 30 × 32 mm, depicting violet flower, probably carnation, (green, violet, red, yellow, black, white, gilding, tendrils in brown ink); fol. 116v: O-initial with gilded elements, 32 × 34 mm (violet, black, gilding, floral tendrils in brown ink); 117v: W-initial with gilded elements, 40 × 35 mm (red, yellow, blue, white, gilding, floral tendrils in brown ink); fol. 123v: painted G-initial with gilded elements, 41 × 41 mm (green, yellow, red, gilding); fol. 128r: G-initial with gilded elements, 35 × 35 mm (blue, white, gilding, tendrils in red ink) and floral decoration on the lower margin (strawberries, ink drawing colorized in green, red, white, yellow and violet); fol. 142v: O-initial with gilded elements, 33 × 33 mm (black, gilding, floral tendrils in brown ink); fol. 155v: painted and historiated U-initial with gilded elements, 35 × 34 mm, depicting violet and yellow flowers, probably Pulsatilla vulgaris (red, black, grey, green, blue, yellow, white, violet, gilding, floral tendrils in violet ink); fol. 189r: painted B-initial with gilded elements, 22 × 22 mm (red, green, yellow, black, gilding, elaborated floral tendrils in violet ink); fol. 252r: painted and historiated D-initial with gilded elements, 26 × 26 mm, depicting violet flowers, probably myosotis (blue, red, yellow, white, green, violet, black, gilding).

column7: One miniature and 16 painted initials, using the same colors and apparently all done by the same artist or workshop that also painted the initial in Vienna, Museum für angewandte Kunst–Barockbibliothek, S 25, fol. 1r.
column8: Very frequently found in the whole manuscript are red and blue flourished initials between 2 and 5 lines high and often decorated with complex foliate tendrils.
Initials. Initials added at the beginning of the 14th century, fol. 1, to the 12th century text

column8: Miniatures; compare the scenes from the life of Joseph, , and leaf in Alan G. Thomas, Catalogue 12 (1963), no. 8. Pächt and Alexander London, BL, Add. MS. 19992
Miniature (coloured drawing) depicting a messenger delivering a letter to St Bernard.
Coloured initials
Illuminated initial, coloured border and initials, rubrics.
Two- to eight-line initials.
Incipit, explicit, and paragraph marks in red. Headings and Jesus’ name underlined in red. Majuscules and minuscules at the beginning of phrases stroked in red.
Headings, paragraph marks, and marginal comments in red. Certain words and phrases underlined in red. Majuscules stroked in red.
Penwork frogspawn decoration on two initials (fols 1r and 16r).
(fols 1r–32v) One- to four-line initials in red marking text segments. (fols 32v–33r) Simple one- to two-line initials.

Extensive use of rubrication. Paragraph marks, virgules, and line fillers in red. Headings, nomina sacra, and quire numerals underlined in red. Majuscules stroked in red. Some passages vertically highlighted in red. Some maniculae (see script) also in red. All executed by the scribe.

(fols 1r–32v) Red headings. The names of the Evangelists in red, Jesus’ name always underlined in red in the gospel harmony. Majuscules at the beginning of phrases stroked in red. (fols 32v–33r) A red heading, one heading and one passage underlined in red.
A single two-line blue initial in Fragm. II, with red flourishing, accompanied by a red heading; alternating red and blue paraphs in the text.
The two-line initial S an archaising penwork design of two dragons.

Headings in red. At the openings of the first three texts, eight-line red and blue lombards with geometric flourishing of the same. Individual sermons introduced by two- and three-line alternate red and blue lombards, with flourishing of the other colour. The scribe adds a few rubricated marginalia (eg fol. 5 and 271 ; in addition, it seems to be him who, checking his text, marked errors in brown ink in the margin, then corrected the text and erased the marginal notes: fol. 31, 32, 42, 70, 71, 130 , 133, 176 ). The texts are divided by larger capitals in the text ink, although item 6 by alternate one-line red and blue lombards. v v v

Headings in red. At textual divisions, blue lombards with red flourishing, four- and five-line at openings of books, three-line for chapters, two-line in the prefatory quires. Red letters in the margins to identify biblical lections, non-biblical materials underlined in red. Running titles for the parts in red preceded by a blue paraph. The text is divided by red-slashed capitals, red paraphs, and in some portions, blue paraphs.

Headings in red. At the openings of the texts and the book divisions of item 1 (fol. 14, 33 and 48), four-line (six for the prologue to item 1) arabesque initials in red, blue, or green, with flourishing or floral patterns in the other colours. Similar two-line examples at the openings of the chapters of item 1 (usually without flourishing). The texts are divided by larger capitals in the text ink, by ochre-slashed capitals in texts 2 and 4.

Canon tables; evangelist portraits. Ornamental headpieces (some with medallions added, sixteenth century). New Testament scenes added, sixteenth century, first half (Hutter, III, no. 95, Abb. 362–83, pl. 1)

column7: Hutter, III, no. 87, Abb. 338–335, Farbtafel II

Decorated initials (Hutter, III, no. 177 and Abb. 631–5).
Good borders
Good initials

On this leaf the gradual and gradual verse are introduced by large initial letters (blue and red), without decoration but the full height of the line of text and stave. These occur throughout the fragments that we have identified from the Gradual, but the only decoration distinctive enough to permit an assessment of a possible dating is that pasted to the boards of Auct. 1Q inf. 1.51 (Bod-Inc. N-098), which has an illuminated initial N with Knospenfleuronnée infilling and pen-flourishing, as well as a pen-work scribal initial. Datable on the basis of the fleuronnée to c. 1450–75 (ex inf. Maria Theisen).
Diagrams
2-line flourished initial in blue and red.
Red initials.
One- and two-line red penwork initials.
Rubrication throughout.
Initials in plain red.
Initials and paraphs in plain red.
Incipit, explicit and titles in rustic display capitals, fol. 1.
Sentences within the biblical text begin with one-line red initials; gloss capitals touched in red on fol. 1 only.

Seventeen-line blank space, now with the opening words of the biblical text ( ) supplied in large display capitals, alternately red and black, with black and red contrasting pen decoration, added probably in the last decades of the twelfth century. Uir erat in terra hus nomini Iob
Rubrics in red, numerous paraphs, underlinings, and marginal notes and pointing hands in red.
Each chapter introduced by a three- or four-line initial in red.
The first initial six lines bigh with reserved foliate designs and penwork ornament.
Full-page miniature, attributed to the workshop of the , who is likely to be identified with . Master of the Prayer Book of Maximilian Alexander Bening (died 1519)
Full-page miniature, attributed to the workshop of the , who is likely to be identified with . Master of the Prayer Book of Maximilian Alexander Bening (died 1519)
Plain KL monograms in red and blue ink in the calendar.
Rubrics in red ink.
3-line gold initial at the beginning of the prologue to John and a penwork initial at the beginning of the gospel .
2- to 4-line blue initials with red penwork at the beginnings of prologues and chapters.
3- to 4-line gold initials on blue and burgundy background at the beginnings of books.
Border made of a gold bar in the right margin with penwork sprays and gold leaves in the lower margin at the beginning of Matthew.
2- to 4-line blue initials with red penwork at the beginnings of prologues and chapters.
Rubrics in red ink.
3- to 4-line gold initials on blue and burgundy background at the beginnings of books.

Handsome vinet initials in blue, pink, orange and gold, sometimes with partial borders, open arts 6–10, and bks 5–9 of 6; red and blue initials flourished in red and violet; blue initials flourished in red; red or blue paraphs; early on running heads in red and blue capitals; red highlighting, underlining and framing of marginal chapter-numbers.

Each homily opens with a handsome large (usually 6-line) red and blue flourished initial, probably by more than one hand. The scribe of the text writes explicits and lengthy incipits in red. As far as Tract. LXVII the numbers are given as running heads in red and blue capitals. Blue, red and green script, and red or blue initials flourished in the other colour, are used in the , as well as red patterned line-fillers. Occasional highlighting in red or yellow. capitula
Plain red initials, paraphs and titles, sometimes missing.

On f. 6 is a red and blue initial flourished in red, blue and violet, with three-sided border; blue initials flourished in red; plain red or blue initials in the ; red titles and running heads with blue paraphs. capitula

Large plain red, blue, green or buff initials, except for a 5-line on f. 30v, blue on a pink ground, with foliage in yellow and orange. Red , diples, and running heads on a separate ruled line. D tituli
As for MS 4, plain initials except for f. 85, a 12-line blue on a pink ground edged with green, enclosing green, blue, white and gold foliage on orange. P
Plain blue initials; red , paraphs and underlining. tituli

Biblical books (and Psalms 26, 38, 51–2, 68, 80, 97, 101, 109) open with fine initials dominated by pink, blue, orange and gold, in the style of , sometimes with partial borders, mostly with simple foliage, sometimes with dragons and other animals. Noteworthy are: f. 1 enclosing Jerome writing; f. 3 (Genesis) running the full length of the intercolumnar space, with the seven days of Creation, f. 167v (Proverbs) with man wielding ornament as weapon; f. 271 (Matthew) with seated cleric writing. Blue initials flourished in red; blue and red chapter-numbers and running heads; plain red or blue initials in the Psalter and art. 2, which also has red or blue paraphs. William de Brailes F I P L

Red and blue flourished initials; red or blue initials flourished in the other colour; extensive rubrication. The decoration is sometimes omitted altogether, e.g. for all of the additional material on fols. 2–7, 191–3v.

On fol. 1 is a large (31-line) and handsome initial in ‘Channel style’, pink, orange and blue with knotwork and interlace, on a gold ground, with red and blue display script. Elsewhere red or blue initials flourished in the other colour. Rubrication by the scribe of the text. P
Blue initials flourished in red; red or blue paraphs; red highlighting.
II and fols. 226–7: blue initials flourished in red.
on fol. 86 two large initials in colours and gold, with a handsome full ivy-leaf border; blue initials flourished in red; red or blue paraphs; red underlining of biblical lemmata.
Blue initials flourished with red, the first with a partial border in the colours; red or blue paraphs.
Blue initials flourished in red; red or blue paraphs; red underlining of lemmata.
A blue initial, flourished in red, prominent red or green paraphs, flourished in the other colour.
Rough red initials and titles; red highlighting and paraphs.

Red or blue initials flourished in the other colour; red or blue paraphs. Art. 33 opens with a large red and blue initial flourished in both colours, thereafter blue initials flourished in red; red titles and running heads. 35.
No decoration art. 34; red paraphs and highlighting art. 35.

On fol. 2v the text opens with a handsome initial running the full length of the page, in ‘Channel style’ with curling tendrils in pink, blue and green on gold, all on a blue and buff ground edged with green; a mask at the top, and a roundel in the middle occupied by four running hares. Other large initials in one of red, green, blue or buff, plain or flourished in one or both of red and blue. Red running heads and paraphs. I

Blue initials flourished in red, red initials flourished in violet; red highlighting and underlining. Art. 9 opens with a blue and red initial flourished in red and violet; coloured diagrams are on fols. 219v, 220v, 221v, 222v, 223, 224, 227; red or blue paraphs. Decoration lacks to arts 7–8, 10–11, 20–1.
art. 22 has blue initials flourished in red, red or blue initials and paraphs, highlighting in yellow. Decoration lacks to art. 23.
Red and blue flourished initials; blue initials flourished in red; red or blue initials and paraphs; underlining in red.
Red paraphs and underlining.
Plain red or blue initials and paraphs, ceasing after art. 12.
Red and blue flourished initials; blue initials flourished in red; red or blue paraphs. Occasional red or blue initials and red highlighting.

On fol. 149 is a 6-line initial , red and blue, flourished in red and violet; red initials flourished in violet, blue initials flourished in red. Red highlighting, paraphs and underlining; yellow highlighting. D

red and blue flourished initials; plain red or blue initials (perhaps intended for flourishing in the other colour); occasional blue initials flourished in red. Red highlighting, paraphs and underlining.
Mostly lacking; sporadic rubrication, red underlining and yellow highlighting.
Unfilled spaces for coloured initials and rubrics.
Unfilled spaces for coloured initials and rubrics; occasional red highlighting.
Books open with large red and blue flourished initials with partial borders; otherwise plain blue initials (probably intended to be flourished in red); red paraphs and running heads.

On fol. 1, in colours and gold, an 8-line historiated initial (Jerome as cardinal with lion, seated before an open book, his hands clasped in prayer) and full framed border (foliage, kneeling bishop), in Flemish style. The rest of the decoration is English: on fols. 150, 195 and 219v 10-line initials on a gold ground with pink and blue insets and coat of arms, the first two Fitzjames, the third the see of Rochester; 8–10 line coloured initials on a gold ground with foliage and sprays; 4-, 5-, or 9-line champe initials; 3-line blue or red initials flourished in red, brown or black; red titles, running heads and initials; blue paraphs, red highlighting.

The first leaf was doubtless excised for its major decoration. Otherwise 2-line initials, purple or green flourished in the other colour, or blue flourished in red; lemmata and running titles in red with purple, blue or green paraphs; highlighting in yellow.

On fol. 1 is a full border and initial in Flemish style, by the same artist as that in MS 23. The border includes Fitzjames kneeling in prayer, and at the foot his arms impaling those of Rochester (he was bishop 1497–1503). The initial encloses Jerome as cardinal, seated at a desk, patting his lion. The remaining decoration is English: books open with 6–10-line initials in colours and brilliant gold, on square grounds with foliage and partial floral borders. That on fol. 20 has the arms of Rochester, those on fols. 39 and 53v those of Fitzjames. Chapters open with 5–7-line champe initials. Commentary on verses open with blue initials flourished with red; red running titles, lemmata and highlighting.

English: fol. 1 has a full floral border and 8-line initial in colours and gold; at the bottom are the arms of Fitzjames of Dorset and Somerset, not an integral part of the border but painted over it. Art. 5 opens with an initial and 3-sided floral border in colours and gold. Arts 2, 3, 4, prols. and commentary on each book in arts 6 and 7, open with large champe initials. Blue initials flourished in red.
Red initials and . tituli

On fol. 14 a nearly full-page in colours and gold with red and blue pen-work spray filling the lower margin, in Channel Style, very like the decoration in All Souls Coll., MS 55 (Watson, , pl. 3(a); Alexander & Temple, no. 889 and pl. lxii); handsome large gold initials on square coloured grounds, fols. 24, 36v, 40, 52v, 56, 65v, 77, 81v, 89, 99, 107v, 113, 119, 130v, 137, 146v, 155v, 163, 166; red or blue initials flourished in the other colour. P All Souls
Blue initials flourished in red; red highlighting.
None; unfilled spaces for initials and rubrics. A few rubrics were supplied by the main scribe.
Uniform throughout; large red and blue initials; smaller red or blue initials. Both types were probably intended for flourishing, not carried out. Art. 1 has red or blue paraphs.

Initials in 1–4 colours of red, blue, green and yellow, often ornamented or arabesqued in a style characteristic of the west midlands and of Worcester Cathedral Priory in particular (e.g. Worcester Cath. F. 24). A bearded face in the on fol. 14v. The 14-line on fol. 1v is in three colours and accompanied by elaborate display-script using all four colours. Q L

On fol. 1 a painted initial and border, the initial excised; most of the border remains, with hound chasing rabbit along the lower bar. Blue initials flourished in red. Red tituli and lemmata from fol. 187.

On fol. 1 a 5-line initial in gold on a square ground, pink and blue with white tracery; a full border of the same. On fol. 389v an 8-line initial, red and blue flourished in both colours. Blue initials flourished in red. Red and sometimes lemmata; red or blue paraphs in the indexes. tituli
Plain red initials and rubrics, often omitted.
Large red and blue flourished initials; blue initials flourished in red.
Red and blue flourished initials; red or blue initials flourished in the other colour; red highlighting.

On fol. 4 an 11-line initial in colours (pink, blue, orange) and gold, historiated in two registers: the Nativity above, Augustine preaching to a cleric below; three-sided bar border with vine-leaves, on the lower limb a hound chasing a ?rabbit (excised). Red and blue flourished initials; red initials flourished with violet, blue initials flourished in red; red or blue paraphs. D

I: initials are highlighted with yellow. II: on fols. 18 and 30 red and blue flourished initials with 3-sided bar borders. Blue initials flourished in red; red or blue paraphs, plain red or blue initials in table (a); underlining in red or ink of text.
Red and blue flourished initials with partial borders; blue initials flourished in red; plain red or blue initials and paraphs; lemmata underlined in red.
Red initials flourished in blue; red highlighting.
Blue or red initials flourished in the other colour; red or blue paraphs; plain red and a few blue initials; red highlighting and spasmodic running heads.
Unfinished: unfilled spaces for coloured initials and rubrics; spasmodic rubrication; red highlighting and underlining.
Blue initials flourished in red. The running heads are accompanied by red or blue paraphs.
Blue initials flourished in red, red initials flourished in ink of text; a few small plain red or blue initials.
Blue initials flourished in red; a few red initials flourished in ink of text; red paraphs and underlining.
Unfilled spaces for coloured initials; highlighting in yellow.
Red highlighting and paraphs.

On fol. 168 a 6-line initial in colours and gold on a square ground, enclosing a master teaching a student, with a 1-sided border, a goldfinch at the foot. Otherwise blue or red initials flourished in the other colour; red or blue paraphs, red highlighting. The remains of a handsome small book. S
Rather rough red initials, , paraphs, highlighting and underlining. tituli

Red and blue flourished initials with partial borders; red or blue initials flourished in the other colour; running heads in large capitals in the colours; red or blue initials and paraphs for . capitula
Plain red or green initials. On fol. 43 is a profile monk’s face as . nota
Blue initials flourished in red; red or blue paraphs.
On fol. 17 is a 5-line initial with full floral border in colours and gold. On fol. 1 is a champe initial with sprays. Blue initials flourished in red; red or blue paraphs.

On fol. 1 a 7-line initial in colours and gold, with 3-sided floral border, in English style of s. xv; blue initials flourished in red; red underlining, highlighting and paraphs, which are used for the running heads.
Red initials, paraphs and highlighting.

In the lower margin of fol. 211 are a skilfully drawn castle and a large pointing hand with sleeve. Blue initials flourished in red; red or blue initials and paraphs. At the head of the rear pastedown is ‘ii magne litere xv par ’. affi
Arabesque initials in 2–3 of red, blue and green. On fol. 1 is a 9-line redQenclosing foliate ornament in the colours. Otherwise plain red or green initials.
Blue initials flourished in red; red lemmata, marginal chapter-numbers and running heads; yellow highlighting.
Red and blue flourished initials with long bar borders; red initials flourished in violet, blue initials flourished in red; running heads in blue and red capitals.
Handsome and distinctive red and blue flourished initials with long borders, enclosing designs of oak and other leaves and wyverns; red or blue initials flourished in the other colour.

Art. 1 opens with a red and blue flourished initial; art. 1 blue initials flourished in red, and red or blue paraphs; arts 3–8 have blue or red initials flourished in the other colour. Art. 2 has red or blue paraphs. Throughout are running heads in red or red and blue capitals. Marginal chapter-numbers to art. 1 are in red, in arts 3–8 in red and blue, throughout associated with red paraphs.

Large and handsome red and blue flourished initials with long borders, incorporating drolleries. To the end of bk. 16 small blue initials, highlighted or flourished in red, open lemmata, which are in red. Running heads in red capitals; highlighting in yellow.
Large and handsome red and blue initials, flourished in the same colours and violet, with long marginal extensions; blue initials flourished in red; red or blue paraphs; red underlining of lemmata.
As for MS 57.

On fol. 1 is an initial (excised) and full border in colours and gold, with ornament of feathers, bezants, flowers and foliage. Scott, , pl. XXVI, illustrates the same man’s work in Balliol Coll. 204 (dated 1461), and comments that he was not English. Very many large coloured initials on squarish gold grounds with sprays of feathers, bezants and foliage. Large dark-blue initials elaborately flourished in red; red or blue paraphs. DDEMB
As for MS 59: a major initial doubtless missing with the lost first leaf. Another initial has been excised on fol. 237v.
As for MS 59. Doubtless an initial and border has been lost with the first leaf. On fol. 115 is a 13-line initial and border in colours and gold; most of the lower margin has been excised.
As for MS 59. Initials with full borders on fols. 1 (the initial excised) and 123 . On fol. 25v the marginal spray of the initial has been excised.
As for MS 59. Doubtless a major initial and border were on the original first leaf.
As for MS 59. On fol. 1 is an initial and full border, the initial excised.
As 59. Major initials and borders are on fols. 1 (mostly excised), 111, 119, 138, 144v, and 149.
Red and blue flourished initials with partial borders; blue initials flourished in red; red or blue paraphs; running heads in the colours.
Blue initials flourished in red; red or blue paraphs.
On fol. 1 is a red and blue flourished initial with 1-sided border. Otherwise blue initials flourished in red; red paraphs, highlighting and underlining. Arts 18 and 20 lack decoration.
Blue initials flourished in red; red or blue paraphs; red underlining.
Red and blue flourished initials; plain blue initials; red , running heads, paraphs, underlining and highlighting. auctoritates
Books open with large and handsome red and blue flourished initials, with partial borders in the colours. Blue initials flourished in red; red or blue paraphs; running heads in red and blue capitals.

On fol. 1 a 6-line initial in colours on a squarish ground, enclosing Thomas preaching to lay persons including a soldier, in the style of the painter, for whom see E. Temple, ‘Further additions to the William of Devon group’, 11 (1984), 344–8 and figs 2–3; Morgan, , II, pp. 22, 128, 153, 161–2. Red and blue flourished initials; blue initials flourished in red; red or blue paraphs. Catchwords and runovers are associated with attractive grotesques in pen-and-ink. Q William of Devon BLR Early Gothic

Red and blue flourished initials; blue initials flourished in red, with short extensions in both colours (cf. MS 107); red or blue paraphs; -numbers in the margins and as running heads in red and blue capitals. quaestio
Blue initials flourished in red; red or blue paraphs.

On fol. 1 is a 7-line initial in colours and gold with stylized foliage, on a squarish ground. Red or blue initials flourished in the other colours; red or blue paraphs. For a while -numbers are given in red and blue capitals in the margins. Running heads in red. quaestio
No decoration.

On fol. 1 is a historiated initial in colours (deep blue and pink) and gold on a squarish ground enclosing the Virgin breast-feeding the Child, before them a kneeling Dominican; two-sided border with grotesques. Red or blue initials flourished in the other colour, the red ones sometimes with short extensions in both; running heads in blue capitals flourished in red; red or blue paraphs.
On fol. 1 an 8-line red and blue flourished initial with full border. Blue initials flourished in red; red or blue paraphs, large ones defining the running heads, which are in ink of text.
Plain red and blue initials.

Red and blue initials flourished in both colours and with partial borders; red or blue initials flourished in the other colour; red or blue paraphs; running heads in red and blue capitals; red highlighting.
Red and blue flourished initials with partial borders; blue initials flourished in red; red or blue paraphs. The have small red or blue initials. Red underlining and line-fillers. capitula
Blue initials flourished in red; red or blue paraphs. Red paraphs accompany the running heads.
None; unfilled spaces for coloured initials and rubrics. From quire 5 rubrication and red highlighting.

Spasmodic, with many unfilled spaces for coloured initials and rubrics, the latter sometimes supplied in a later hand. Plain blue initials, doubtless meant for flourishing in red, which was only added on fol. 1; alternating red and blue initials in the to bk. 1; rubrication, yellow highlighting. capitula
Hardly any decoration; a blue initial with unfinished red flourishing on fol. 110; otherwise only yellow highlighting.
Blue initials flourished in red; red or yellow highlighting early on.
Plain red or green initials.
Probably the same decorator throughout. On fols. 1 and 79 are red and blue initials with 1-sided borders in the colours; plain red or blue initials and paraphs.
Unfilled spaces for coloured initials and rubrics.
Unfilled spaces for coloured initials and rubrics.
Unfilled spaces for coloured initials and rubrics.
Unfilled spaces for coloured initials and rubrics.

The opening initial red and blue, flourished in the colours; red or blue initials flourished in the other colour; the diple in red, red highlighting and rubrication. After a while the decoration was omitted.
On a red and brown initial with a long marginal extension terminating in a comic king’s head; small red or brown initials, red and paraphs, all the decoration soon ceasing.
None; unfilled spaces for coloured initials and rubrics.
Art. 1: on a red and blue flourished initial with 3-sided border; blue initials flourished in red; red or blue paraphs. Otherwise unfilled spaces for coloured initials and rubrics.

On is a red initial, arabesqued in green, blue and buff. The other books of art. 1 open with handsome decorated initials outlined in ink of text, washed in blue and green (sometimes yellow), associated with red and green display script. Art. 2 opens with an initial of this type, with red and blue display script; otherwise initials in blue, red, or green, sometimes ornamented in a second colour. Scarcely any green is used after .
Fols. are blank but for a crude unfinished pencil sketch of a man on , perhaps of s. xiii.

Initials in colours and gold: on fol. 2 initial and 3-sided border; on fols. 112, 162, 184, 244, initial and 2-sided border; on fols. 34, 75, 95, 108, 113 (2), 114rv coloured initials and sprays. Otherwise blue initials flourished in red.
Unfilled spaces for coloured initials and rubrics.
Small red and blue-green initials
Blue initials flourished in red; red or blue paraphs.
None: unfilled spaces for coloured initials and rubrics.
Blue initials flourished in red; red or blue paraphs. At the foot of fol. 235v is a pencilled calculation apparently of the number of initials.
Blue initials flourished in red; red or blue paraphs.
On a 5-line red and blue initial and 3-sided border; blue initials flourished with red; red or blue paraphs.
Unfilled spaces for coloured rubrics and initials.
Red and blue initials, probably intended for flourishing; red or blue initials and paraphs.

On fol. 1 is a 5-line in pink, blue and gold enclosing St Thomas teaching two clerks, with 3-sided border, on the lower limb a hound chases a hare; red or blue initials flourished in the other colour; red or blue paraphs; red highlighting. Q
Red or blue initials flourished in the other colour; red or blue paraphs; running heads in red and blue capitals.
Art. 1: On fol. 1 a 7-line red and blue , flourished and with a 3-sided border in both colours; blue initials flourished in red; red or blue paraphs; running heads in capitals of the colours. O
Art. 2: unfilled spaces for coloured initials and rubrics; red running heads, paraphs, underlining and highlighting.

On is a 10-line initial in pink, blue and gold, on a square patterned ground, enclosing the Crucifixion flanked by a nimbed saint with a book, and a kneeling clerk catching the blood in a lidded bowl; full border with running hounds, rabbit, hare and stag . Large and handsome red and blue initials with 1-sided borders; red or blue initials flourished in the other colour; red or blue paraphs; red highlighting and underlining; running heads in capitals of the colours. M

On fols. 1, 114, 146, 181 (opening books), large blue and gold initials flourished and with full borders in red and blue; red and blue flourished initials; red or blue initials flourished in the other colour; red or blue paraphs.
Each alphabetical section opens with a blue initial flourished in red; otherwise red initials flourished in blue-black.
Art. 2: red initials, paraphs and underlining.
Art. 1: handsome red and blue flourished initials with 1-sided borders; numerous red or blue paraphs; red marginal titles and running heads; highlighting in yellow.
Unfilled spaces for coloured initials and rubrics.
None; unfilled spaces for initials and rubrics.
Unfilled spaces for coloured initials and rubrics.

A blue initial flourished in red; plain blue initials; yellow highlighting.

Prologue and books open with exquisite historiated initials in colours and gold, on square grounds and with short extensions: 8-line C, enclosing Peter Lombard as seated bishop, expounding his own book to three clerks; 6-line V, enclosing the Trinity; 7-line Q, enclosing God creating Eve; 6-line C enclosing the Nativity; 7-line S enclosing God the Father, the world in one hand, the other raised in blessing, above the Good Samaritan. Blue initials flourished in red, sometimes with short extensions in both colours; in the smaller red or blue initials flourished in the other colour; running heads in flourished capitals of the colours; in the attractive patterned line-fillers in the colours. capitula capitula
Two painted initials in Bolognese style on fol. i , otherwise blue initials flourished in red, red initials flourished in violet; red or blue paraphs. v
Large red and blue initials flourished in red and with partial borders in the colours; blue initials flourished in red; art. 3 red paraphs, highlighting and underlining.
Blue initials flourished in red, on fol. 1 with a partial border in the colours; red or blue paraphs; underlining in red. Decoration ceases from fol. 227.

As for MS 115. Red and blue flourished initial with partial border in the colours; red or blue initials flourished in the other colour; red or blue paraphs.

Blue initials flourished in red; red or blue paraphs; in art. 7 small plain red or blue initials.

On fols. 1, 36, 39v, 58v, 77, 98, 113v and 169 large and handsome red and blue initials with 1-sided borders in the colours; blue initials flourished in red; red paraphs. Many unfilled spaces for rubrics. Good pencil sketches in the margins: , a hand holding a coin; a half-length pharisee; the head of Constantine; the head of Thomas Becket.
None; unfilled spaces for coloured initials and rubrics.

On fols. , and handsome 7-line initials with curling foliage in blue, purple, green and gold; blue initials flourished in red, red initials flourished in violet; red or blue paraphs in the . Some major initials and all rubrication omitted. capitula
On a large red and blue flourished initial; blue initials flourished in red; red or blue paraphs. Red highlighting in art. 2.

Splendid 9- or 10-line historiated initials in colours and gold with partial vinet borders open each book : on a square ground, enclosing Vincent seated expounding his text, his library at his elbow; a full border, on the lower limb a hound chases a hare; enclosing God the Creator; enclosing horned Moses expounding the Ten Commandments to the Israelites; A enclosing seated king with sword, giving orders to two knights; in the background a Master expounds a text; a hound chases a hare across the lower limb of the border; enclosing seated king with sword, a hound and hare at the foot; with coiled foliage, a patch excised from the foot; , in the upper register a seated queen with sword, below the Nativity, a hound chases a rabbit at the foot; , to the left two kings with swords, divided by a fortified tower; on the right, the Assumption of the Virgin; a hound chases a hare at the foot. Red or blue initials flourished in the other colour, with long 1-sided borders; running heads in capitals of the colours; red highlighting. Q D E A I R M

Splendid 9- or 10-line historiated initials in colours and gold with partial vinet borders open each book. The major initials are as follows: 3-line initial with curling foliage and 3-sided border, a hound chasing a hare across the lower limb; enclosing seated king with sword, judging two men pushed forward by a soldier, hound and hare as before; enclosing a vigorous siege scene; hound and hare as before; with curling foliage, a hound; a patch excised from the other end of the lower limb; enclosing a beheading of a young man before a seated king, a knight restraining a pleading father; hound and hare as before; beheading of three individuals before a seated king; hound and hare as before; enclosing a monk fondling a young ?girl in a tower, another appears before a seated king with sword; hound and hare as before. The initials to books X and XV have been excised. N G V I R F

Splendid 9- or 10-line historiated initials in colours and gold with partial vinet borders open each book. The major initials are as follows: 2-line with 3-sided border, a hound chasing a hare across the lower limb; with coiling foliage and 2-sided border, the hound and hare at the foot mostly excised; enclosing seated emperor with erect sword, before him an armed king with shield backed by knights; two excisions at the lower limb have doubtless removed hound and hare; at the top a grotesque archer takes aim at a flying bird; 5-line with coiling foliage and partial border, a hound and rabbit as before; with coiling foliage and partial border, hound and hare as before; 5-line with 1-sided border; with coiling foliage and partial border, mutil. at the foot (doubtless removing hound and hare); 5-line with coiling foliage, 2-sided border with hound and hare as before; with coiled foliage and 2-sided border, hound and hare as before; P with coiling foliage and 2-sided border, hound and hare as before; 6-line with partial border; with coiling foliage, partial border, hound and hare as before; with coiling foliage and 1-sided border, hound and hare as before; with coiling foliage and dragon, 1-sided border, hound and hare as before. A S A O M U T U H U M T C

Splendid 9- or 10-line historiated initials in colours and gold with partial vinet borders open each book. The major initials are as follows: 3-line with coiling foliage and 2-sided border, on the lower limb hound chases hare, another hound peeps from the foliage; enclosing seated emperor with erect sword, in conversation with a king and his retainers, full border, across the lower limb two hounds pursue a stag, a hare looks on (a late medieval hand has sought to copy the stag in ink near the head of fol. 3v); 2-line with coiling foliage, 3-sided border with hound and hare as usual; with coiling foliage and 3-sided border, across the lower limb a ?beagle (with long floppy ears) and hare; 3-line with coiling foliage and 2-sided border, hound and hare as usual; 2-line with coiling foliage and 3-sided border, seated beagle and hare; with 3-sided border, hound and hare as usual; with coiling foliage, 3-sided border and beagle and hare as usual; 2-line with 3-sided border, hound and hare as usual; A with coiling foliage, beagle and hare as usual; 4-line with 2-sided border, crouching hound and hare; with coiling foliage and 3-sided border with hound and hare as usual; 4-line with 2-sided border, beagle and hare; with 2-sided border, beagle and hare. U R U H U U D A T T O T D

Books open with handsome large initials, typical English professional work of the period: on 9-line with coloured foliage on a square gold ground, with 3-sided border; smaller initials in gold with white tracery on pink and blue grounds, sprays of green leaves and gold bezants in the margins (champes) on fols. , , , , , , . Red and blue flourished initials with 1-sided bar borders; blue initials flourished in red; red or blue paraphs; red and blue running heads and marginal chapter-numbers. At the foot of is pencilled a calculation of the number of coloured initials in the book.

On fols. 1 and 51 are large and handsome red and blue flourished initials with partial bar borders. According to G. Pollard, in the unpaginated Addenda and Corrigenda of 1940 to S. Gibson, (Oxford, 1931), the initial on fol. 1 is by the same hand as that in the University’s Registrum A, fol. 8, which he dates to 1311–13. This will apply to the initial on fol. 51 as well, and perhaps to others in the set. Blue initials flourished in red; red and blue paraphs and running heads. At the ends of quires are pencilled the number of the coloured initials and paraphs. Statuta Antiqua

Red and blue flourished initials; blue initials flourished in red; plain red initials, red or blue paraphs; red and blue chapter numbers in the margins and as running heads. At the ends of quires are pencilled the number of the coloured initials and paraphs.

Red and blue initials with 1-sided bar borders; blue initials flourished in red; red or blue paraphs; red and blue chapter-numbers and running heads. At the end of quires the decorator has totalled the number of initials in pencil.

In Parisian style. Fine historiated and decorated initials in gold and colours, flourished in red and blue, open the text and sometimes also the gloss of each book: 22-line with God the Creator; the opening initial of Rom. lost with the excised leaf after fol. 1; 12-line gold on pink and blue ground with fine curling foliage perhaps once silver; fine arabesque in red and blue; 24-line with half-length Paul holding a scroll; fols. , with foliage and pen-flourishing in purple, green, orange and white; fol. 22-line with half-length Paul in the act of writing (a fine representation of a scribe at work); 22-line with half-length Paul holding a scroll; 20-line P with Paul being lowered from the walls of Damascus; 19-line with half-length Paul holding a book; fols. , 24-line and 41-line gold on red and blue ground with foliage; 22-line with half-length Paul holding scroll and gesturing; with half-length Paul gesturing; gold on pink and blue ground; 19-line violet enclosing a gold ground with coloured foliage; 11-line gold on a blue ground with fine curling foliage perhaps once silver. In the text red or blue initials flourished in the other colour; occasionally green flourished with red; in the gloss plain red or blue initials; red underlining of lemmata and marginal auctoritates; running heads in red and blue capitals. Handsome historiated and decorated initials in Parisian style, in colours and gold. Some are protected with curtains of red silk. 8-line ; 15-line (eatus) with foliage and ‘white lions’, in a small roundel King David seated and harping, all on a blue square ground; 8-line (David anointed by Samuel: Ps. 26); 8-line (Ps. 39); 17-line (A man beheads a fallen knight: Ps. 51); 9-line (Ps. 52); 11-line (Ps. 68); 12-line (Ps. 80); 11-line (Ps. 95); 9-line (A priest prays before an altar, the hand of God blessing: Ps. 101); 12-line (Ps. 109) enclosing the Trinity: God seated with cruciferous nimbus, in His left hand a small roundel with the Lamb of God, in His right, raised in blessing, the Holy Spirit as dove. Red or blue initials flourished in the other colour; plain red or blue initials, red running heads, underlining of biblical lemmata in the gloss. In the lower margin of is a design of oak leaves. Red and blue flourished initials; red or blue initials highlighted or flourished in the other colour; plain red or blue initials, red or blue paraphs introduce passages of gloss, associated with initials in the other colour; two-colour chapter-nos in the margins and running heads.

Handsome 9–12-line initials in colours on burnished gold grounds, in ‘Channel Style’ (curling foliage and elongated beasts): fols. , (standing nimbed prophet with book, blessing), , (seated nimbed prophet with scroll, blessing), (seated nimbed prophet with scroll), , , (seated nimbed prophet with scroll), , , , , . Red or blue initials flourished in the other colour or both; small plain red or blue initials; running heads in capitals of both colours.

Unfilled spaces for major initials; red or blue initials flourished in the other colour; conspicuous red or blue paraphs with flourishing in both colours, extending into the margins with pretty leaf, fruit and daisy motifs; running heads in capitals of both colours.
On fol. 6 are two large initials, the first red and blue, flourished in both colours, the second blue flourished in red; plain red or blue initials; marginalia in red; red underlining of lemmata.

On is an slightly longer than the written space, in blue, pink, green and brown, with curling foliage; large red and blue initials flourished in both colours; red or blue initials flourished in the other colour; red or blue paraphs; running heads and marginal chapter-numbers in capitals of both colours. The minor initials and paraphs have long extensions in both colours into the lower margin. I
On fols. , 6-line initials in colours and gold with full borders (cf. Scott, , pl. 4); blue initials flourished in red; blue or red paraphs; red highlighting and running heads. DEMB

English. On is a 12-line in colours and gold with full border (cf. Scott, , pl. Ia); 6-line champe initials fols. , , , , , , ; blue initials flourished in red; blue paraphs, red highlighting; running heads in red with blue paraphs. S DDEMB

Handsome large initials with foliage in colours and gold fols. , , , ; red and blue flourished initials; a few small blue initials flourished in red; red or blue paraphs. Art. 10 has unfilled spaces for coloured initials and rubrics.

The works open with handsome red and blue arabesque initials; otherwise red or blue initials, sometimes with a little ornament or flourishing in the other colour. Exceptionally handsome historiated initials in colours and gold with decorative extensions, in Oxford style, with preliminary marginal sketches in pencil, open each book: those on fols. 1 and 28 excised; 11-line U enclosing ‘scientia’ as seated queen, sheltering in her cloak other disciplines also shown as queens; I full length of the page, with standing doctor pointing upward; 12-line M enclosing two philosophers disputing; 12-line E enclosing seated philosopher holding a representation of ‘ens’; 10-line O enclosing two men raking up stubble, threatened by a man with a knotty club; 11-line D enclosing two seated philosophers disputing; 12-line D, ditto; 10-line C, two seated philosophers disputing, between them a hierarchy of angels topped by a bust of the Deity.
Red and blue flourished initials, red or blue initials flourished in the other colour; red titles. On f. 289v is a table of consanguinity in red and blue.
Marginal drawings in pencil or ink of text on fols. , , , .

Blue initials flourished in red; large blue paraphs, sometimes flourished in red, in the text; small plain red initials in the gloss; running heads in both colours, between ruled lines; red highlighting.

Art. 1 opens with a 9-line initial in colours and gold with 3-sided ivy-leaf border. Art. 2 opens with a red and blue flourished initial.
