Art. 2 has plain blue initials flourished in red and plain red or blue initials. Unskilful marginal drawings in pencil, s. xiv, on fols. , .

Twenty-one large and exceptionally handsome 9-line initials, mostly in colours and gold, with foliage or figures, on square grounds and with partial borders: (12-line) E, enclosing a lion, a squirrel, two hounds hunting a hare, the whole on a background of oak-leaves; at the foot of the border three hounds hunt a stag; A enclosing oak-leaves, a squirrel and rabbit; at the foot of the border a hound chases a hare; D enclosing birds in boughs above fish in water; at the top of the border is a singing bird; at each end of the foot a rabbit and hound; initial ditto, at the foot of the border are rabbit, hound and two fish; O enclosing a pair of cattle mating; at the top of the border a running hare, at the foot, a hare, and two dogs and two small birds mating; S with oak-leaves, hound and bull, many animals in the border, in a continuous line across the foot; O enclosing a stallion and ?dead mare, sprays of oak with a bird; in the border a rabbit, a hare and a donkey; M enclosing oak foliage and two striped quadrupeds of uncertain identity; in the border a pair of ?weasels, a pair of birds, a pelican in her piety, a parrot, a hive of bees and another bird; D enclosing a clothed man and woman copulating in woodland above, below a woman rocking a crib; at the foot of the border are two leaping hairs, a clothed man and woman copulating, and a woman tending her baby before a fire; P enclosing man and woman in bed; on the foot of the border a clothed man and woman copulate; D, enclosing a line of four dogs, below birds singing in a tree; in the border two dogs and two birds; D enclosing God the Creator holding the globe of the world containing trees and water; in the border a hare and three dogs; C enclosing animal and human body parts; more at the foot of the border; E ditto; C ditto; a phallus on the foot of the border has been erased; E ditto; Q enclosing oak foliage, a hare, two dogs mating, a hound chasing a boar; in the border a rabbit and two horses copulating; G enclosing oak foliage with a hare, mating birds and hares, in the border mating boars and birds, partially erased; D enclosing oak foliage and two birds with nest and eggs; in the border are a songbird, a cock, and a cock and hen mating; D enclosing oak foliage and two lions mating; in the border are ?foxes and boars mating; D enclosing oak foliage; in the border are two birds and ?foxes mating. Much writing in capitals, and some numerals and framing, in red and green. On f. the birth of Jesus is marked by a large chi-rho with interlace and foliage ornament, within a double rectangular frame, in ink of text filled with red, green and yellow.

Handsome arabesque initials in red, dark green, blue and sometimes pink associated with display script in the first three colours; plain red, blue or green initials; the have red or blue initials, plain or flourished in the other colour or both. capitula
On the leaf lost before f. 2 were probably a full-page miniature, and on the verso certainly IN PRINCIPIO.
Large decorated initials in similar style and colours: fols. H, M, H, H, H, C, Q, H, Q, C, Q, F, Q and C, M, N, Q, A, T.
Numerous smaller initials, flourished or arabesqued in red and green, sometimes also blue and yellow; red highlighting.
Red or blue initials flourished in the other colour. Running heads in red, at first contemporary with the text, later s. xiv, including art. 3; rubrication.

Thirty-one historiated and decorated initials of exceptional quality, in Mosan style. Historiated initials, some very large, outlined in ink of text, filled with red, blue, green and buff: f. nearly full-page P, Joseph before Pharaoh; f. I as standing nimbed Moses with book and budding rod; f. H, The Creator with Moses, The punishment of Chora and his brethren; f. M, the return of the ark and the idol of Dagon; f. P enclosing bust of David, crowned; f. D, ditto; f. I as standing Iosaphat, crowned and with drawn sword; f. H with king kneeling before an altar whereon an idol in the shape of a ram; f. P enclosing seated king with crown, sceptre and blank scroll; f. A enclosing King Antigonus crowned and seated, with orb and sceptre, at his feet his predecessor Alexander being placed in a coffin by two men while his wife mourns; f. T with hanging man; f. unpainted H enclosing mounted armed knight.

Large and handsome initials in colours and gold with partial borders: f. 11-line D, the author presenting his book to the pope, the figures deliberately scraped; 3-sided border; f. S mutil.; f. 10-line V enclosing mass celebrated in the king’s presence, in roundels heretical books being burnt, with 3-sided border; f. 9-line B; f. 8-line C; f. 10-line O; f. 11-line C; f. 12-line P; f. 8-line U. On f. a 4-line gold M on a green square ground, filled with red; gold initials flourished in blue or violet; blue initials flourished in red; the have small initials of types 2 and 3, and line-fillers in red, blue and gold; running heads in red with blue initials flourished in red; red underlining and highlighting. capitula
Modest initials in colours and gold fols. (2), (2), one of 14 lines on f. 142; red or blue initials flourished in the other colour; red or blue paraphs.
Red and blue flourished initials with long extensions; red or blue initials flourished in the other colour; red or blue paraphs, red highlighting. A good deal of the decoration is omitted from II.
Red and blue flourished initials with long extensions; red or blue initials flourished in the other colour; red or blue paraphs, red highlighting.

Many handsome 4–8 line arabesque initials, mainly on squarish grounds edged with green, in red, blue, green and pink; blue or green initials flourished in red, red initials flourished in blue; plain initials in the colours or ink of text.

Florentine. Large initials have been excised; most of the 3-sided floral border remains on f. ; gold initials on blue, pink and green grounds, fols. , , , , , , , , , , ; rubrics, numbers of and table in pink; thereafter initials of individual blue. Rime Rime
On a red and blue flourished initial with partial border, in Parisian style; red or blue initials flourished in the other colour; red highlighting, underlining, chapter-numbers and running heads.

On a 14-line initial A, pink and blue in a gold frame, enclosing Henry VI as a boy, seated and holding two crowns and with two sceptres in his lap, a scroll inscribed ‘Viuere pacifice michi sit et utrique corone’; handsome full border with magpie. Arts 5 and 6 (fols. and ) open with 13-line gold initials on gold and pink grounds, patterned and enclosing beasts, each gorged with a coronet and bearing an inscribed scroll, the second with full border: an eagle ( , Edw. I?, ‘Laus legislate uolat undique cum probitate’), a leopard ( , Edw. III, ‘Viuat uis legis quia ius est gloria regis’), a hart ( , Ric. II, ‘Sauns departier’), a dog ( ; Hen. IV, ‘Ma soueraine’), and a horned dog-like spotted animal ( ; Hen. VI, ‘Vn sanz pluis’). On a gold S on pink and blue ground (champe); 6-line blue initials flourished in red; red or blue paraphs; red highlighting. A marginal sketch of a leopard rampant on .
A cross outlined in ink of the text, tinted yellow, and a prayer by the scribe in majuscules on : †κ(ύριε) βοήθει τώ σώ δούλω Πέτρω καί συγχώρισον τάς Άμαρτίασ αύτοϋ, ώς καί ϕίλ(ος)†
On the verso a framed, full-page portrait of Chrysostom in the same technique. An ornamental headpiece on , and some simple pen-work ornament elsewhere; titles and initials are in carmine.

Since a rubric on fol. 10v refers to Anselm as , these postdate his death and almost certainly the publication of the to his , both by Eadmer, which has been dated to the mid-1120s. The rubrics can be dated to the second quarter of the 12th century. They do not meticulously follow the original instructions (visible e.g. on fols. 18r and 46v) and may have been added later. (The labelling Anselm as might have been the rubricator’s own wording.) beatus Miracula Vita incipit beatus

Seventeen handsome 10-line illuminated initials (some with long extenders) are used for the beginnings and major divisions of works, on fols. 1 , 12 , 13 , 14 , 24 , 44 , 62 , 75 , 84 , 98 , 121 , 132 , 155 , 174 , 197 , 207 , 231 . The gold letters are on crimson and blue grounds traced with white. The grandest initials also make use of orange. r r r v r r r r r r r v r r r v v

There are rubrics, red and blue paraphs, red underlining of lemmata, and in C(i) some touching of small capitals with yellow ochre, red line-fillers, and ornamental frame-ruling in red. Wording for the rubricator to follow often survives in the margins.

A major initial has presumably been torn away from the top of fol. 1. What remains is of two types: (1) illuminated initials; (2) arabesque initials, as follows. Despite the several styles, only one artist may be involved: the several types of initial in group I are linked by various features and the arabesque initials are linked to initial I(a) by the arabesque decoration at the foot of the extender, which seems to be original. Parallels to several features can be found in manuscripts from Hereford, Gloucester, and Lanthony. Lanthony (Lambeth Palace, MS 63 fol. 142 ) and Hereford (Oxford, Jesus College, MS 66 fol. 4) have initials with blue spikes as our initials 1(a) and 1(g); gold tracery on a pink base, very similar to our initials 1(a) and 1(b) is found in Oxford, New College, MS 35, fols. 1 and 3 (of unknown origin: owned by fellows of New College in 15th century, one of whom had a connection with Abingdon); Hereford Cathedral MS O. VI. 7 fols. 2 and 90 have blue bases with white triple-dot pattern which also occurs on the initials of New College MS 35. Arabesque initials from Gloucester are in the same style as those in our manuscript. Not recorded by Alexander and Temple. 1(a) (fol. 25 ), 10-line P with extender, gold letter with pink bow infilled with gold tracery. The letter is entirely outlined in blue with little spikes protruding from all sides and its foot ends in blue and red arabesques with bunches of grapes. v (b) (fol. 47 ), 11-line P with extender, gold letter with pink bow on blue square and extender also on blue. On the blue are patterns of three white dots. v (c) (fol. 90 ), 12-line P with panelled bow and extender, gold enclosed by crimson/orange, all enclosed by blue. Inside bow are curved tendrils, crimson/orange and buff, with green and buff leaves. On the blue and gold are patterns of three white dots. v (d) (fol. 96 ), 10-line P with extender, fully sketched tendrils in the bow but with only the gold of bow and extender painted. r (e) (fol. 99 ), 11-line P with panelled bow and extender, gold enclosed by crimson/orange and all enclosed by green. Inside bow is an animal with a long head biting the bow of the letter. r (f) (fol. 125 ), 10-line P with extender. Curve of bow and centre of extender are blue, dotted white. Inside bow is an animal with a long tail which it is biting; cf. initial (e). ra (g) (fol. 125 ), 10-line M. Gold letter with crimson/orange and buff tendrils and green, crimson/orange and gold leaves. Blue spikes are on the outsides of the verticals. rb 2(a) (fol. 66 ), 10-line P with extender. Bow is green on outside of curve, buff on inside, all with white dots; extender is green on left, buff on right, divided by wavy white line. Delicate arabesque patterns inside bow with orange tendrils, shaded blue and green leaves. Three- and five-grape pattern. r (b) (fol. 81 ), 10-line P with panelled bow and extender, blue enclosed by buff. Inside bow are coiled green tendrils with buff and crimson/orange leaves. r (c) (fol. 115 ), 10-line P with extender. Outside of bow and left side of extender are green, inside of bow and right-hand side of extender are blue, both divided by wavy red line dotted white. The green and blue have a pattern of triple dots in white. Delicate arabesque patterns in bow with red and blue tendrils with green, blue, and red leaves, gold stars or suns, and red grapes. r (d) (fol. 123 ), 10-line P with extender. Bow and extender are blue with red and white centres. Arabesques in bow have blue tendrils with green, blue, and red leaves, and red grapes. r v v r Other decoration consists of plain 2/4-line red, blue, and green initials, rubrics, red paraphs, and red marginal authorities. Our Plate II reproduces details of fol. 25 . v
Two-line plain red initials, with guide letters. Rubrics with guide-wording for rubricator in margins in scribe’s hand. Red paraphs; some red running titles ‘ ’ and ‘1’ etc. on facing pages. liber

A major initial has presumably been lost with the removal of the original quire 1 and the first leaf of the present quire 1. On fol. 1 is a 6-line red and blue lombard with extender and there are similar initials, with the addition of mauve flourishing, at the beginning of the other books. v
The initial on fol. 45 has a man-beast astride a tendril and that on fol. 95 has two men-beasts wrestling. r r

Fine illuminated initials have presumably been lost from the beginning of book I but others survive before the capitula and the beginning of the text of books II–IV. They are in the form of rectangles with a deep blue or brown base colour on which is a letter filled with blue interlace traced with white.
Alexander and Temple, no. 675, ‘French’.
None.

Throughout there are 2/4-line red and blue lombards flourished in the other colour; 1-line red and blue initials; rubrics; red-and-blue running book numbers in upper margins and chapter numbers in side margins.

A 4-line red-and-blue lombard at beginning of text, elsewhere 2-line red and blue initials (longer if with extenders) flourished in the other colour; rubrics; red running numbers, to fol. 146 only; lemmata underlined in red.

3/4-line blue lombards flourished red at beginning of each item. Red and blue paraphs. In the sermons the lombards do not always succeed in guiding the reader through the text of item 4, since the scribe left spaces for them at the wrong places.

Alexander and Temple, no. 314, describe the decoration as ‘fine’ but that exaggerates the quality, which is modest. The gold initial on fol. 1 is inhabited by a Dominican friar expounding a text and has a very long painted extender which acts as a bar-frame border round most of the text area. Some painted initials at the beginning of books have a very little gold. r
There are also ⅔-line blue lombards, flourished red, rubrics, red and blue paraphs, red line-fillers and stroking.
1/5-line plain red and green initials. Rubrics; red paraphs and stroking of letters; lemmata underlined red.

Sparse decoration, inadequate as to guide a reader through the text. On fol. 1 are two 6-line green-and-red lombards with arabesque infilling, otherwise initials are plain green or red, 1/3-line. There are rubrics and a few red lemmata, and some marginal authorities, sparsely cited compared with MS Bodl. 706 ( 2605), are underlined red. ordinatio SC

Red, blue, and green initials, 7/10-line, some with arabesque decoration, at beginnings of chapters; 3-line mostly plain red or blue but some with extenders and 1/2-line throughout. Rubrics, red stroking. Some marginalia are encircled in red. Alexander and Temple, no. 110.
On fol. 1 is a 9-line red-and-blue lombard which is extended to form a bar-frame border. Lombards throughout are otherwise 3/4-line and there are red and blue paraphs.
There are 2/3-line blue lombards flourished red, with extenders; red and blue paraphs.

Fine illuminated borders on fols. 1 , 13 , and 158 (Alexander and Temple, no. 520), Oxford work by the decorator of MS 60 ( ). For a characterization of his work see the headnote to MSS 51–68 in Watson, , pp. 85–87. r r v Artist A Exeter
Good quality red-and-blue lombards, 2/7-line, the larger ones with half-borders, all infilled with leaf pattern,
also plain red and blue 2/5-line initials; red and blue paraphs, red underlining.
No colour. Occasional headings in ornamental bastard anglicana.

A 6-line red-and-blue lombard on fol. 251 (250 ) (and smaller ones throughout) infilled with delicate leaf and tendril patterns, also blue lombards flourished red, and red lombards flourished mauve. Rubrics, red paraphs, red underlining. r r
No decoration

5/9-line blue lombards flourished red, with extenders, at beginnings of books, i.e. on fols. 1 , 101 , 167 , 249 , 263 , those on fols. 101 , 167 , and 249 being of very good quality. Rubrics; red-and-blue running titles (book numbers). Alexander and Temple, no. 281. r r v r r r v r
No decoration
Alexander and Temple, no. 288 (s. xiv ). 2/4

English-style decoration, round which the marginal gloss has been neatly written, consists of a 9-line illuminated historiated initial at the beginnings of books (that for bk. 1 has been excised), extended into a border in gold, crimson, and blue with white dots and/or lines on the colour throughout. Two/three-line initials at the beginnings of are in this style throughout, presumably superimposed on Italian ones. The subjects of the four surviving English historiated initials are (fol. 86 : bk. 2, rubric ) a judge(?) expounding to, or admonishing, two men, all standing; (fol. 163 : bk. 3, rubric ) a priest saying mass; (fol. 217 : bk. 4, rubric ) a priest joining a couple in matrimony; (fol. 226 : bk. 5, rubric , miniature damaged) two seated figures (? accusers) with another(?) behind and between them. tituli r De iudiciis r De vita et honestate clericorum r De sponsalibus et matrimoniis v De accusacionibus [et iniquiis]

Original decoration is probably English but could pass as Italian in style: blue lombards flourished red, red lombards flourished blue or grey in Italian style; rubrics; red-and-blue running numbers for books; lemmata underlined red.
None.
Larger initials, 4/6-line, are in the same style and hand as those in B but there are also red-and-blue line-fillers. Occasional headings are in ink.
As C, but without line-fillers and with rubrics.
As C, but without underlined lemmata, paraphs, and line-fillers and with rubrics.
On fol. 1 a 27-line J in red and blue, elsewhere 3/4-line blue lombards flourished red, and 1-line red and blue initials; blue and red paraphs, lemmata underlined red. r
*1: none.

2: fine 8/10-line blue lombards at the beginning of books, infilled with red-and-blue arabesques, with extenders. Throughout, 1/2-line blue initials flourished red, rubrics, running book numbers in blue flourished red, red stroking, red line-fillers (circlets). Alexander and Temple, no. 204.
otherwise 2-line blue lombards flourished red, and red flourished blue, with extenders. Blue and red paraphs and blue-and-red running head numbers.
2, a quite good 7-line illuminated initial with extender on fol. 1 (Alexander and Temple, no. 232), r

Red paraphs and stroking.

Plain red 2/3-line initials.
1/5-line red initials, rubrics, underlining.
fol. 50 : diagrams in the scribe’s hand which are part of the text. r
There are 2/4-line red initials, red paraphs and rubrics.
67 : diagram. v
Fols. 41–46 : The only colour is red bracketing. r
There are 2-line red initials, line-fillers, paraphs and underlining, and rubrics.

*5: 3-line illuminated initial and extender (blue, green, brown, orange) by artist of *3; 2/3-line blue lombards flourished red, 1-line blue initials, rubrics;

9: as 4, but coloured running titles are replaced by elegant uncials in ink, written across both columns between ruled lines, and plain initials are replaced by red and blue initials flourished in the other colour, and red-and-blue initials;
10: 2/3-line initials flourished red, 1-line blue and red initials. Alexander and Temple, no. 451.

4: at beginning of books, plain blue initials, 4-line but some with long extenders; also 3/4-line red-and-blue initials. Otherwise 1-line red, blue, and green initials, red-and-blue running titles, rubrics, blue paraphs;
*7: as *6 but without illumination;

*3, *4–*7: are mid-15th-century Oxford style related to the manuscripts in ’s donation (MSS 51–68); the decoration of fol. 203 of the present manuscript is almost certainly of fol. 1 of Bod. Lib., MS Bodl. 795 ( 2644) written in Oxford in 1435 ( , no. 114, pl. 358) and of Bod. Lib., MS Hatton 73 ( 4199) (Scott, , ii. 287, q.v. for others) and MS 53 below (our ). For a characterization of his work see headnote to MSS 51–68 in Watson, , pp. 85–87. Roger Keys r by the hand r SC DMO SC Later Gothic Manuscripts Artist A Exeter

column8: *8: 1-line red and blue initials, rubrics;
Before each psalm are 4/5-line lombards, blue flourished red. Lemmata underlined red; red stroking. Alexander and Temple, no. 426.
On fol. 1 is an illuminated 4-line initial extended to form a half-border. Main colours are blue and brown. A hole in the lower margin suggests that a coat of arms has been excised. r

Snakes are common: on fol. 38 a snake of 63 mm length is vertical in the margin and at one point is represented as disappearing into and emerging from the membrane; an elegant 45 mm snake is on fol. 43 ; there are also a bird’s head, animal heads, and human feet. In the bottom margin of fol. 86 is a pencil drawing of a group of buildings, including a battlemented wall or tower, a domed tower, and a building with a red roof. Alexander and Temple, no. 150. v v v

Four-line blue and red lombards, flourished blue and red, at the beginning of each psalm, some with extenders. Also similar ten- and six-line lombards at the beginnings of the commentary on the ferial psalms, 26 and 38, and plain one-line blue and red initials. Lemmata underlined red. One red line-filler; rubrics. Fragments of acanthus leaves drawn in margins probably indicate points of interest, as may occasional heads. Sometimes a foot stands on the top of an acanthus leaf (fols. 33 , 65 , 71 ) and there are occasional hands, not pointing but open as if saying ‘behold!’ (fols. 34 , 36 ). v v v v r

1: one 6-line and one 2-line blue lombard flourished red on fols. 1 and 2 respectively, both extended into borders. A coat of arms has been excised from the lower border on fol. 1 and may have been duplicated by another in the same position on fol. 2 which appears to be original: see further, History. The decoration otherwise consists of two-line blue lombards flourished red at the beginning of each psalm, red and blue paraphs, red-and-blue running numbers of psalms; lemmata underlined red. r r r r
2: red and blue two-line lombards, red and blue paraphs.

At the beginning of the first homily is a blue and red interlace initial surrounded by muddy brown and green and enclosed in a square, but most other initials are plain blue-and-red 5-line initials filled (probably later) with patterns in the same brown and green except when they are long (e.g. J) and provide no scope for infilling, and are therefore left unadorned except for marginal arabesques. Book 1 has red running book numbers; book 2 black running book numbers dotted red, both being guided by roughly written crayon notes in top margins, such as ‘O vi. partis prime’, ‘O v. partis ij.’ There are rubrics in both parts. Alexander and Temple, no. 136. melia melia

Lacks the first leaf, presumably one with a decorated border. At the beginning of parts 2–9 (fols. 1 , 8 , 10 , 26 , 79 , 81 , 111 , 134 , 150 , 160 ), there survive fine illuminated initials with extenders which develop into bar-frame borders, the main colours being flame or orange, brown, and dark blue. v v r v r v r v v v

2/4-line blue lombards flourished red, red and blue paraphs, rubrics, red running titles with blue paraphs, line-fillers consisting of ornamental groups of dots and a comma. Alexander and Temple, no. 401.

Throughout there are 2/5-line blue lombards flourished red, red and blue paraphs, rubrics, lemmata underlined in red. Running titles have 1-line red lombards flourished mauve, and blue flourished red.

Eleven fine illuminated initials, mostly inhabited or historiated, with page-length marginal extenders. At least one is presumably lost with the first leaf of item 2 but all others survive. Although the style is a little unsophisticated the execution is very good and the decoration makes much effect by the use of bold colours, usually on a dark blue or occasionally crimson background delicately traced with white. Some of the subjects can be identified as having a connection with the text, others seem to have none. The subjects are (fol. 97 ), ch. I in ‘Ia. Est’, an abstract design with a spear-bearing figure seated on the top; (fol. 114 ) ch. M in ‘Mach[i]na’, an abstract design; (fol. 18 ) ch. B in‘Baburra’, a seated teacher seemingly counting things off on his fingers; r (fol. 24 ) ch. C in ‘Cachinnor’, a jester; r (fol. 48 ) ch. D in ‘Dauir siue dabir oraculum Dei’, a seated figure ?writing on a scroll; r (fol. 57 ) ch. E in ‘Ebron ciuitas’, a tonsured figure seated on a ?throne, perhaps one of the three patriarchs referred to; v (fol. 64 ) ch. F in ‘Facio’, Mary, seated and crowned, a sceptre in right hand and a scroll in left hand with ‘Aue Maria’ on it; v (fol. 82 ) ch. G in ‘Gabriel’, an archangel; v r v (fol. 131 ) ch. N in ‘Nablum uel Nablath’, a seated figure apparently instructing or admonishing but without the musical symbols the text might suggest; r (fol. 137 ) ch. O in ‘Obelus’, a roosting bird of prey; v (fol. 161 ), ch. Q in ‘Quatuor’, a grotesque with a tail and a human face. r In the margins of fols. 64 and 161 are crayon drafts of the completed initials. v r

Otherwise decoration consists of red and blue lombards flourished in the other colour, red and blue paraphs, and underlining of lemmata. Alexander and Temple, no. 279; pl. xviii no. 279 reproduces F and detail of border fol. 64 . v
B, one-line plain red and blue initials; red and blue paraphs.

A, four-line blue-and-red lombards flourished in the same and extended as bar-frame borders on two sides of page; two-line blue lombards flourished red; red-and-blue running book numbers, lacking on fols. 235 –46 ; blue and red paraphs. r v

On fol. 1 a 5-line blue-and-red lombard, flourished red and extended in red and blue into a bar-frame border with mauve flourishing; 2-line blue lombards, some extended, flourished red, throughout; blue and red paraphs; lemmata underlined red. r

At the beginning of books, 4/11-line blue-and-red lombards flourished red, some with extenders; at beginnings of prologues, 2/3-line blue lombards flourished red. Otherwise 1-line plain red and blue initials flourished in the other colour. Red-and-blue running titles and marginal book numbers; rubrics. There is guide-wording for rubricators in bottom margins but, although spaces were left for others, only those for Baruch and Apocalypse were inserted. Alexander and Temple, no. 178.

Five/six-line initials precede each psalm, illuminated with full leaf borders when on pages with a miniature, otherwise with painted and illuminated borders. They are filled with leafy spirals and hybrid or animal figures.
Gold 1-line initials on pink-and-blue panels; painted line-fillers with geometric, animal, floral, or leaf motifs.

On the possible artists see under History, below. Our Frontispiece reproduces fol. 68 . Sandler illus. 259–61 reproduces miniatures on fols. 54 , 68 , 99 respectively, all reduced; Dennison (see below), pls. 29, 33, 34 reproduces details of miniatures on fols. 116 (full size), 54 (reduced), 102 (enlarged) respectively, also pls. 39 and 40, details fols. 132 (enlarged), 126 (enlarged), and pl. 42 (full page, fol. 109 , reduced); Alexander and Temple, no. 306, pl. xxi reproduces fols. 54 , 68 , all reduced. r v r v v v r v v r v r

Six miniatures have evidendy been lost from the beginning of the psalter and at its divisions. The following remain (the identification of the subjects follows Sandler, , ii, no. 102): Gothic Manuscripts , Doeg slaying a priest (Ps. 51); above, David playing the harp before an ox-cart pulling the Ark, and below, Michal on the ramparts of Jerusalem pointing upwards towards David (Ps. 68); , above, the death of Absolom, and below, a messenger brings the news to David (Ps. 97); , David(?) within a castle kneels in prayer, a bust of the Lord above (Ps. 101); , above, death of David, below Solomon asleep (Ps. 109).

1, all pages have illuminated borders, each page with two medallions, one in the lower border showing the occupations of each month and the other in either the inner or the outer side border showing the zodiacal signs. James, see bibliography, describes them. 2–5, in the lower margins of fols. 7 (9 )–12 (14 ) are the arms, alternately of and England. r r v v Bohun

For factual descriptions see James, 7–22; for greater detail and aesthetic judgements Sandler, ii. 150–1. Alexander and Temple, no. 316; pl. XXII, 316a, reproduces fol. 31 (33 ), 316b reproduces fol. 123 (125 ), both reduced. v v v v

Watson's Plate III reproduces fol. 32 . James, see bibliography, reproduces all historiated initials, including full pages of fols. 31 (33 ), 32 (34 ), 115 (117 ); Dennison, ‘Oxford, Exeter College, MS 47’ see bibliography, reproduces 20 pages or details. r v v r r v v

In the rest of the book the system of illustration consists of (1) ornamental frontispieces to the ferial divisions; (2) historiated initials to psalms, canticles, collects, etc. The frontispieces and the initials to psalms and canticles form a connected series, telling the Bible story from the Creation onwards. Of the original ten frontispieces (for psalms 1, 26, 38, 51, 52, 68, 80, 97, 101, 109) all but two have gone (fols. 31 (33 ), 32 (34 ), for psalms 51, 52) as well as illustrations to 34 psalms. Dennison, ‘Oxford, Exeter College, MS 47’ see bibliography, distinguishes five hands working in three campaigns: (1) fols. 18 (20 )–75 (77 ), quires 4–11; (2) fols. 7 (9 )–17 (19 ), quires 2–3; (3) fols. 1 (3 )–6 (8 ) and 76 (78 )–124 (126 ), quires 12–18. Of these, D, the senior artist, can be identified as Fr , who worked in the Bohun family home at Pleshey, Essex, for many years: see History, below. memoriae, v v r r r r v v r r v v r r v v r r v v John de Tye, OESA
On fol. 1 is a 7-line blue and red lombard flourished red, otherwise decoration mainly consists of the same in 2/5-line size. Some letters are touched with ochre and there are blue and red paraphs. r
Two-line red initial, rubrics, and red stroking of capitals throughout. 1 has red and sometimes black running book numbers.

By , for a characterization of whose work see the headnote to MSS 51–68 (Watson, , pp. 85–87). Ten-line illuminated initials with elaborate floral sprays in outer and central margins form surviving borders on fols. 1 , 82 , 83 , 102 , 124 , 169 , 184 , 202 (i.e. the beginnings of all Old Testament books except Deuteronomy which was excised). There are 3-line gold initials at the beginnings of chapters throughout, on various kinds of blue- or pink-coloured base with white tracery; also red and blue paraphs. Artist B Exeter r v r r v r r r
Three-line initials at the beginnings of chapters are plain blue and not illuminated. There are a few red and blue paraphs.

Of the same type as in MS 51 but by . Illuminated borders on fols. 1 , 20 , 95 , 96 by Artist D (John Bray: see Watson, , pp. 85–87, q.v. also for a characterization of his work: see also Watson, , Plate IV). On fol. 1 the border has been lost from the outer and lower margins but borders on fols. 20 , 37 , 54 , 95 , 96 , 103 , 128 , and 150 are intact; all others have been lost from the beginnings of books. Spray decoration is in the same style and possibly from the same Oxford shop as is found in Cambridge, Trinity College, MS R.14.5 (Scott, , no. 103), Oxford, Oriel College MS 6, and Bod. Lib., MS Hatton 73 ( 4119). For the manuscripts see Watson, , pp. 85–87, n. 10. Artist D r r r r Exeter Exeter r r r r r r v v v Later Gothic Manuscripts SC Exeter

Of the same type as in MS 51 but by (the ‘Chaundler’ illuminator, for whom see Watson, , pp. 85–87 n. 10, also for a characterization of his work). Major illuminated borders at ferial divisions survive on fols. 92 , 159 , 214 (Pss. 26, 38, 52) very similar to those in Cambridge, Trinity College, MS R.14.5 (Scott, , no. 103), Oxford, Oriel College, MS 6, Bod. Lib., MS Hatton 73 ( 4119), and MS 36 above. There are no lombards or plain red or blue initials. Lemmata are underlined in red, unlike those in MSS 51 and 52, which are underlined in ink. Artist A Exeter r r v Later Gothic Manuscripts SC

Of the same type as in MS 51 but by (on whom see Watson, , pp. 85–87; q.v. also for a characterization of his work). Ten-line illuminated initials with elaborate blue, pink, and green sprays in outer and central margins remain intact at the beginning of all psalms except before Ps. 69 (excised) and on fols. 26 (mostly lost through damp), 39 , 79 (both partly lost through damp), 83 , 86 , 90 (all damaged by damp). Very fine decoration remains on fols 69 and 134 , before ferial divisions at Psalms 80 ( ) and 97 ( ) respectively. There are red and blue paraphs, red underlining of lemmata, and a red-and-blue linefiller. Dr Dennison regards this volume as the latest by Artist A in the series comprising MSS 51–68, remarking that the illumination shares characteristics of hands of artists A and B: the ornamental motifs are those of A while the slightly ‘hotter’ palette suggests acquaintance with the pigments used by . It thus bears the typical hallmarks of a transitional manuscript, perhaps suggesting some working contact between the artists. Artist A Exeter v v v v v v r v Exultate Deo Cantate Domino Artist B

Item 1 fol. 1 has an illuminated border, illuminated initials at the beginning of chapters, red underlining of lemmata, blue and red paraphs, and rubrics. Item 2 has a similar border on fol. 120 , and blue and red paraphs. Item 3 has a border on fol. 181 which contains ’s arms, red and blue paraphs, and illuminated initials for chapter beginnings. r r r Keys

Of the same type as MS 51 and by the same artist, , for a characterization of whose work see Watson, , pp. 85–87. There are borders on fols. 1 , 48 , and 49 . Artist B Exeter r r r

Border on fol. 1 and spray initials throughout. Blue running titles in uncial, and marginal chapter numbers. r

Of the same type as in MS 51 but by , for a characterization of whose work see Watson, , pp. 85–87. Artist A Exeter
On fol. 1 is an illuminated border incorporating ’s arms. r Roger Keys

Major borders remain intact on fols. 1 (Hosea), 45 (Joel), 86 (Jonas); 95 (Micah), 121 (Nahum); partly lost on fol. 192 (Zachariah) and entirely lost from before fols. 57 (Amos) and 248 (Malachi). Lemmata are underlined red. There are no paraphs, rubrics, or plain initials. r r r v v v r r

Of the same type as in MS 51 but by , for a characterization of whose work see Watson, , pp. 85–87. Artist C Exeter

There are illuminated initials for chapters, blue and red paraphs, lemmata underlined red, blue running titles and book numbers.

Of the same type as in MS 51 but by , for a characterization of whose work see Watson, , pp. 85–87. A major illumination before Matthew has been excised but others survive on fol. 130 (with ’s arms in the lower border) and on fol. 132 . Artist A Exeter v Keys r
Of the same type as in MS 51 but by , for a characterization of whose work see Watson, , pp. 85–87.. Artist A Exeter
There are major decorations in borders on fols. 1 and 4 , illuminated initials for chapters, lemmata underlined red, red and blue paraphs, blue running-titles and chapter numbers, rubrics. r r
Of the same type as in MS 51 but by , for a characterization of whose work see Watson, , pp. 85–87. Artist A Exeter
Illuminated initials with sprays begin each chapter (that on fol. 4 was cut away) and there are rubrics, red and blue paraphs, blue running titles, and chapter number and lemmata underlined in red. v
Major decoration, a border, is on fol. 1 , but, probably for the sake of ’s arms of which only a tiny part remains, half of the bottom border and the whole outer border have been torn away. r Keys
Major decoration, illuminated borders, is on fols. 1 , 114 , 195 . r r r

There are illuminated initials with sprays at beginnings of chapters. There is only one rubric, and red and blue paraphs, and there are no blue running titles or chapter numbers as in most volumes in this series.
Of the same type as MS 51 and by the same artist, , for a characterization of whose work see headnote to MSS 51–68. Artist B

On fols. 1 , 238 , 250 , and 274 , are 8- and 10-line illuminated initials. The same artist probably did sprays in Oxford, New College, MS 288 (Scott, , no. 114). At the beginning of some chapters are 3-line gold initials on a pink and blue coloured base with white tracery. There are red and blue paraphs and lemmata underlined red. r v v v Later Gothic Manuscripts
Of the same type as MS 51 but by , for a characterization of whose work see Watson, , pp. 85–87. Artist C Exeter
Of the same type as MS 51 but by , for a characterization of whose work see Watson, , pp. 85–87. Artist A Exeter

There is an illuminated border on fol. 2 (and another was no doubt lost from before item 2); otherwise illuminated spray initials, blue running titles, red and blue paraphs, lemmata underlined in red. r

Otherwise 3/6-line red-and-blue lombards, flourished red, and 3-line plain blue initials, which seem to be in the same hand throughout; also rubrics, red running numbers of sermons, red marginal authorities, and chapter divisions. The Rector’s Accounts, ut supra, record payment in autumn 1484 to ‘John Bray pro ligacione et illuminatura duorum voluminum operis Hugonis de Vienna, xx pro incathenacione eorundem in libraria’, one of which is certainly this volume and the other probably MS 60. On him see also headnote to MSS 51–68. Alexander and Temple, no. 593. d
Of the same type as MS 51 but mainly by . On fol. 1 is an illuminated border on three sides by Artist D: see headnote to MSS 51–68; q.v. also for a characterization of his work. Artist D (Bray) r
At the beginnings of books and prologues of books are 4/8-line decorated initials, some with a touch of silver, and some (as on fol. 59 ) with very elaborate decoration. v
There are also marginal drawings of animals, human heads, human and animal grotesques, and fish. All the decoration is very crude but the animal drawings have some style: see pl. 133. DMO
Elsewhere 2-line red and blue lombards flourished in the other colour, some with elaborate marginal decoration.
B, 1-line red initials and red underlining of lemmata. Alexander and Temple, no. 705.
Plain 1/2-line red initials, red paraphs and stroking.
None. Spaces left for coloured capitals and headings remain empty.

On fol. 1 , for the prologue, is a 6-line illuminated capital O on a blue and purple background, extended down the inner margins with flowers, leaves, and gold blobs; all rather rubbed. Otherwise the decoration is 3-line blue lombards flourished red, with ochre stroking of the first words of lines, and infilling of loops of cadells and of extended ascenders and descenders. Large spaces were left at the beginnings of some books, presumably for miniatures, but these were filled with very large colophons. Alexander and Temple, no. 596. r

On fol. 18 is a 10-line illuminated initial with extenders forming a bar-frame border on three sides; blue and rose are the only colours. On fols. 99 , 138 , and 175 are 5-, 7-, and 6-line illuminated initials respectively, each with colours blue and crimson. Elsewhere 1/3-line blue lombards flourished red, blue paraphs flourished red, red running titles. Alexander and Temple, no. 385. r v r r
None. Spaces were left for initials.

Confined within a rectangular E-shaped frame on fol. 1 is an illuminated border with white vine tendrils on a green, blue, and crimson background spattered with gold spots. On fol. 143 is an initial in a similar style but not illuminated. r r

Otherwise capitals are plain blue and red, 2-line. There are rubrics and red underlining of characters’ names. Not recorded by Alexander and Temple.

On fol. 3 an illuminated border, white vine-tendrils on a blue background with crimson and dark green infilling and the green spattered with gold dots. At the foot is a defaced coat of arms on a gold background surrounded by a green laurel wreath with a blue and a red riband to left and right respectively. r

At least two initials might be considered historiated: (a) , the head of homily 6, has an angel within the initial; (b) , the head of homily 9, has an angel and perhaps a human in conversation.

In booklet 2, the rubric is written in decorative red lombards across the top of the page.

The are slightly more elaborate in presentation. has a larger capital (13 lines), with a winged centaur shooting a bow in the demivinet, and there are marginal titles for each entry in text ink on alternating red flourishing headed by a blue paraph and purple flourishing headed by a gold paraph. indices

At lesser divisions, 2-line lombards in alternate blue on red flourishing and gold on violet flourishing, including line-fillers of the same and often with elaborate marginal extensions. In the extensions, many small animal and human heads (with washed ‘rounding’).

At the heads of the parts, 9- or 10-line blue and violet champes with gold leaf and demivinets of the same, with floral sprays and buds, and animals either in the foliage or the initial (most elaborately, that to part 12, , with a wyvern, a bagpiper, an animal blowing on its tail as if it were a recorder, a woman, and a hawker).
Headings in red.
Running titles in red (after not on every page) with full references to parts and chapters, as well as to the biblical text discussed.

At the heads of chapters, 2-line blue lombards on red flourishing with red and blue bars along the column.
In Psalms, larger 7-line capitals at the heads of Nocturns.

Running titles in blue lombards on red flourishing (both lacking in Psalms). In item 2, each entry preceded by a 1-line blue lombard on red flourishing, 2-line high examples at the alphabetical divisions.
At initia, 6-line red and blue lombards on red and blue flourishing with penwork extensions.
Headings in red to identify texts, although many within individual books remain unfilled, especially in Psalms, sporadically in major prophets and in the New Testament.

In the intercolumnar space of fol. 4, a seven-compartment illustration, running the full length of the writing area: the works of the six days, with the Sabbath drawing defaced. A large square, presumably with an armorial device, has been cut out at the foot of the leaf and repaired with recent vellum. At the head and foot, gold, blue, and violet stylized borders; at the top a wyvern and centaur with bow, at the bottom a parrot and peacock, two monsters (human torsos, serpent middles, and legs and feet of lions) armed with swords and shields atop wyverns.

At chapter headings, alternating 3- or 4-line slaty blue or red lombards on restrained flourishing of the other colour; alternate 1-line lombards of the same to break up the text. Through the first three books, up to (the end of quire 3), the alternation includes red capitals on green and green on red.
Running titles in red provide book numbers.
For the other books, 6-line champes of blue and violet on gold leaf grounds or (for 1 especially) a gold leaf letter on violet ground.
Large painted capitals at the opening of each book.

On , a 15-line high ‘P’, with descender down whole page, of gold leaf on violet ground with vines, flowers, and dragons; the first three words of the text in uncial 3-line gold capitals on a slate-blue ground.
On , instructions for the rubricator, written vertically along the leading edge, where they should have been fully cut off, still survive.
Many initials repeat the dragon, vine, and flower motif, or use other animal shapes.

The Gospels are introduced by 4- and 5-line arabesque capitals (many larger I’s) in gold leaf with green, blue, and red, with abstract geometrical decorative designs; the homilies proper have 3-line arabesque capitals in green, blue, pink, or red, usually with some attenuated repetition of the same design.

The text prefaced with a painted frontispiece on four levels: the signs of the zodiac, twelve men exhibiting the influence of these constellations, the stars (or planets generally), and seven men with rays shining on them exhibiting the appropriate influence.

Jonathan Alexander assigned the work to the London illuminator in ‘William Abel “lymnour” and 15th Century English Illumination’, in Artur Rosenauer and Gerold Weber (eds.), ([Salzburg]: Rezidenz Verlag, [1972]), 166–72 at 167 (no. 15 in his list of twenty-one Abell MSS). For the most contemporary survey of Abell’s work, with a reference to our MS, see Scott 2:264–5. Following Stratford (348 n. 68), Scott argues (1:68 n. 4) that the frontispiece was copied directly from Bedford’s presentation copy, now Lisbon, Biblioteca d’Ajuda MS 52,XII,18. There are two illuminated initials, in the hand also responsible for our MS 26:

Illuminations and decoration of our MS are frequently discussed and reproduced, e.g., Temple figs. 42 (fol. 2), 43 (fol. 81v); Bishop 3 and the accompanying plate 5 (fol. 6v); Wormald, no. 51 (77) and plate 2 (fol. 2); ASIllum 7–8,9 and plates 7, 8, 14a and b (fols. 2, 81v, 26, 27); J. J. G. Alexander and C. M. Kauffmann, English illuminated Manuscripts 700–1500 (Brussels: Bibliotheque royale, 1973), no. 3 (22–3); 0. Pächt, Hunt Exhib, xvii.1 (73); Janet Backhouse et al., The Golden Age of Anglo-Saxon Art 966–1066 (London, 1984), no. 32 (55) and fig. 32 (54). See also AT nos. 2 and 4 (3) and plate i (fol. 2). Alexander and Temple are certainly wrong to separate fols. 1–4 categorically from the remainder (and appear to have thoroughly missed the text run-over on fol. 7); on this basis, the drawing may have been part of the original Gregorian programme, protected, just like the contents table (and the head of Cura pastoralis, if fol. 7 is integral) by blank leaves. Thus, the drawing might be dissociated from those on fol. 81v, on leaves supplied when the MS was expanded to include the two saints’ lives.

On fol. 2 (plate III), a full-page drawing of Christ in red with a book and cross; on fol. 81v, a blank page, three sketches of figures (one an angel) and two sketches of interlace patterns. The illustration of Christ was drawn before the text was written (the scribe carefully tried to avoid the figure, but in three minor instances wrote over the paint).

For discussion of the drawings, major pieces of mid to late tenth-century illumination, see most recently Temple, no. 13 (42), heavily dependant upon Francis Wormald, English Drawings of the Tenth and Eleventh Centuries (London, 1952), esp. 25, 63, and 74. Wormald draws attention to the similarity of the figure to that of the slightly earlier ‘Dunstan miniature’ in BodL, MS Auct. F.4.32 and further notes connections with the drawing of Boethius’s Philosophy in Cambridge, Trinity College MS O.3.7 and of the Trinity in Paris, BN, MS lat. 943 (the Sherborne Pontifical, probably a direct copy). Temple identifies the initials with Wormald’s ‘Type II (b)’. Further discussions appear in Barbara Raw, ‘The drawing of an angel in MS. 28, St John’s College, Oxford’, Journal of the Warburg and Courtauld Institute 18 (1955) 318–19; and Robert Deshman, ‘The Leofric Missal and Tenth-Century English Art’, Anglo-Saxon England 6 (1977), 145–73; and a cautionary note, Richard Gameson, ‘La Bible de Saint-Vaast d’Arras et un manuscrit anglo-saxon de Boéce’, Scriptorium 52 (1998), 316–21 at 318 n. 15.

Two illuminations:
Alternate red and blue 1-line lombards at chapter divisions; chapter numbers in the margin in alternate red and blue roman numerals prefaced with alternating red and blue paraphs.
At book initia, large, variably sized red and blue lombards on flourishing of the same.
Liturgical readings indicated in red in the margins.

: an initial with vine and leaf pattern and a dragon in blue, violet, and green on gold leaf with a full-column marginal bar in gold and blue, an angel near the page foot and a floral design in a gold square at the head of the initial.
Running titles with alternate red and blue lombards to indicate books.
Small capitals in text ink at the heads of verses.
See , dating , and plate xii . AT no. 219 (23–4) s. xiii 3/4
In text 2, 8-line red and blue lombards on flourishing of the same at the heads of the alphabetical sections, 1-line alternating red and blue lombards at the heads of individual entries.
Two-line arabesque capitals at chapter divisions, alternating green on red flourishing, red on blue flourishing, and blue on red flourishing.
In the table at the head, frequent leaf line-fillers on and some extended penwork flourishing in text ink and red at the page foot.
At book divisions, 8- to 12-line red and blue arabesque capitals with vine infills in red, blue, and green.
Running titles with the book number in text ink; frequent marginal indications of authorities.
Headings in red.
Sporadic 1-line red arabesque capitals within chapters.
, apparently to fill a break in the text, has a rectangular vine and flower design in the three colours.
See . AT, no. 129 (16)
Chapter lists at the end of each book have entries introduced by alternate 1-line green, red, and blue capitals.
Red running titles to indicate the biblical book (ending at fol. 117v, a quire bound); some effort to supply them in pencil in later portions.
Headings in red.
At the heads of books, a line of alternating red and blue 2-line arabesque capitals with flourishing.
Sections within books set off by 2-line arabesque capitals, alternating red and blue with flourishing of the other colour; inset glosses begin with 1-line alternating red and blue arabesque capitals.

On fol. 1ra a very damaged 25-line I in gold leaf (originally with violet-brown infill, now faded?) on a dark blue ground. At fol. 52va (the start of Joshua, similarly fol. 62rb, Kings), an 18-line L in gold with blue infill on a violet-brown ground. Similar rather crude champes later: 6-line at Tobit (fol. 101ra), 8-line for the gospels (126va), 7-line for Acts (162rb).
See , dated . AT, no. 654 (65) c.1200

Extensive marginal finding guides for subjects, in the hand of Robert Flemmyng (see Provenance), usually in a darker ink, in a hand similar to but more erect than that of the text (only sporadic examples, ).
Running titles in text ink give book numbers or titles in the upper margin leading edge (none in , ).
Red and blue 7-line lombards at heads of texts and books (the guide letters on several occasions in anglicana).
Chapter numbers in the margins in this ink.
Headings in red.
At text openings 7-line red and blue lombards on red and blue flourishing; at internal divisions, 2- and 3- line alternating red and blue lombards on flourishing of the other colour.
Blanks for rubrics usually unfilled (some instructions vertically in the margins, and many later identifications).
A later hand has supplied psalm numbers in the margin. (s. xv?)

At heads of individual psalms, 3- and 4-line high arabesque capitals, usually green with some red infill, but often red with green plant shapes and occasionally blue with red and green (two 5-line examples on fol. 1).

Headings in red or alternate lines of red and green (blanks for them not always filled at the head of the book, up to about fol. 50); the opening example in two lines, red and green, of rustic capitals.
See , no. 45 (8), dating AT c.1150.
Many capitals with ochre wash, also applied to marginal diples to indicate quoted portions of the Psalter.
Some running titles and chapter numbers added later, at various times—in lead, rubric, etc.
No headings. At the heads of the texts, 8- or 9-line red and blue lombards on flourished grounds of red with blue.
In some quires, the paraphs have long descenders running into the lower margin.
Glosses introduced by large alternate red and blue paraphs, usually with a 1-line lombard in the other colour.
Alternating 2-line red and blue lombards at verse- heads.
Headings, not all filled, in red.
Two-line red roman capitals at chapter heads (6-line for the prologue), parts of opening lines in capitals, sometimes in red.
Chapter numbers in alternate red and blue roman numerals marginally.
A 9-line red and blue lombard at the head, on red vine-work with blue touches and flourishing; a smaller and rather more stylized example at the beginning of Lamentations.
Glosses introduced by large alternating red and blue paraphs, sometimes with enlarged lombards in text ink.
Running titles in alternate red and blue lombards (Iere mie throughout).
Headings in red, for the alphabetical divisions within Lamentations only.
Painted initials at the head of each epistle.
The first blue and violet on a gold-leaf ground, with Paul nimbed in gold and holding a scroll.
See . AT, no. 101 (13) and plate vi
The gloss is relatively undivided, with occasional 1-line capitals in text ink.
No headings. Verses in the biblical text introduced by alternate red and blue 3-(gloss-)line arabesque capitals.
Running titles identify the epistle, in blue on versos and red on rectos through , thereafter red, until they end at , as do additions to the column for authorities.
Marginally cited authorities in red.

At the other initia, blue on red (or the reverse) with blue, violet, green, and orange vine, leaf, and floral shapes on gold leaf. For the prologue , a very different style, gold leaf on a blue ground with blue and red flourishing.
All textual divisions have penwork initials in the ink of the text.
Where spaces have been left for rubrication, they are unfilled (guide letters survive).
Entirely unadorned.
All headings in the text ink.
Regular red running titles to identify the biblical book.
Prologues and biblical books introduced by alternating 6-line green and red arabesque capitals (8 lines in the prologue).
An attempt in quire 1 only (and very sporadically thereafter) to mark authorities in red in margins.
Chapter numbers added in the upper right corner of rectos and provided in the margins, . s. xv
Headings in red.
One-line alternating red and green arabesque capitals to break up the text.
The biblical text in red, followed by the commentary in black ink.
Ornamental text ink strap capitals at the heads of musical portions, often with included human heads, more usually leaf forms.
Written in both red (liturgical instructions especially) and black, with music.
See , dating AT, no. 453 (45) s. xv . 2/4
Frequent 3-line extended blue paraphs on red flourishing.

Within sections, major divisions marked by 2- and 3-line blue lombards on red flourishing (very occasional unflourished 3-line champes, e.g. fols. 61, 88v); smaller divisions alternate 1-line blue and red lombards on flourishing of the other colour.

At major divisions, large champes (eight lines on fol. 1, others usually five lines) with demivinets (a full vinet on fol. 1) in violet, blue, gold leaf, orange, and green—all very faded through damp.

(the head of Genesis): a half-column long gold-leaf and blue I on a gold leaf and green ground, with an internal vine and circle motif and three illustrated lozenges: God moulding a globe, God creating Eve from Adam’s side, Adam and Eve clothed and arguing.
See , dating , and plate x . AT, no. 186 (20) s. xiii 2/4

There are two illuminations: a half-column long gold-leaf, blue, and violet F on a brownish-violet ground, with floral terminations; within the letter, the tonsured Jerome teaching Ambrose from the book; the first text line is in gold leaf on a (faded) green ground.

In the Psalter, 2-line alternate red and blue lombards on flourishing of the other colour at the heads of individual psalms; 6- and 7-line initials of this type at the opening of the nocturns. One-line alternate red and blue lombards at the heads of verses.
Chapter numbers in the margin in alternate red and blue roman numerals.
At the heads of books, 7- to 9-line red and/or blue lombards on red flourishing, usually with the first text line in 2-line high red and blue lombards on red flourishing.

The text is occasionally broken (far from always at the traditional chapter divisions) with alternate red and blue 1-line lombards, occasionally with red paraphs (early on, there are a few red-slashed capitals).
Running titles identifying the book in alternate red and blue lombards (routinely cut into, sometimes cut away; none for Nehemiah).
Headings in red for books, frequently with guides surviving in the gutters (after , usually unfilled).
Headings and marginal notations in red.
At the head of internal divisions, 2-line alternate slatey blue and red lombards with pen-work of the other colour.

Although the illumination at the head of book 1 has been excised, the illuminated letters at other major divisions survive: (the prologue): an 8-line red and blue lombard with green and gold (as well as red and blue) leafy infill;
a large green and blue S, its ends animal heads and filled with vine and leaf design and with animals, on gold leaf.
See . AT, no. 89 (12) and plate 6
: God creating Eve from Adam’s side, on gold leaf within a blue initial on diapered red ground;
, the Nativity, on gold leaf inside a red initial on a diapered blue ground;
Running titles, only up to fol. 46v (book 2, dist. 5), thereafter supplied in pencil by a hand probably of s. xv.
The marginal authorities are introduced by alternating red and blue 2-line lombards, some with exaggerated descenders into the lower margin.

Ten-line red and blue lombards on flourishing of the same at the head of the text and other book divisions (unfilled for book 2, fol. 44ra). That for the index to book 4 (fol. 105) is green and red and extended into a floral border; at the start of book 4 (fol. 107ra), a 4-line high blue lombard on red flourishing.
Headings in red for chapters; authorities in the marginal columns also in red.
At the heads of the books, 6- and 7-line arabesque capitals, red on red and green flourishing.
Chapters introduced by alternate 2-line red and green arabesque capitals on flourishing of the other colour.
On fol. 1, extended red and green vine-work to form a bar border.
See AT, no. 144 (17), dating s. xiii in.
Sentences typically introduced by a capital in the text ink, occasionally by red paraphs or red and green (occasionally blue) 1-line arabesque capitals with flourishing of the other colour.
Individual entries headed by 2- and 3-line red lombards on red flourishing; the argument divided by red paraphs.
At the head of the prologue and of individual letters in the alphabetically arranged text, 3- and 4-line blue lombards on red flourishing.
In Manuscript 1, unfilled blanks for rubrics; occasions for the sermons and biblical sources added in the margins in a contemporary hand; one original rubric in text ink at .
No decoration in any of the three books; the scribes all left blanks with guide letters for capitals at text divisions, none of them filled.
Three- and four-line blank spaces for capitals at the heads of texts, all unfilled with guide letters; some red underlining and rubrics on and .
Occasional running titles and divisions marked in the margins, all in text ink.
Headings and names of sheriffs and their years in red, with red brackets in item 2; a heading in red for item 4.
At the head of item 1, a 5-line lombard in text ink on marginal flourishing, unfilled blanks at the heads of items 2 and 3.
In item 1, the scribe’s running titles indicate subjects of individual books; frequent marginal ‘Nota’ marks by the scribe.
A 5-line blue lombard on red flourishing at the head; individual entries introduced by 2-line examples.
The five tree figures outline a complete Christian instructional programme:
Headings in red.
A single ochre line down the centres of pages for the main genealogies; the circles for members of subsidiary branches are connected by red and blue lines.
See , dating the MS and associating it with . AT, no. 510 (50) s. xv med. Oxford
‘Querenda’, showing the four cardinal plus three theological virtues and their ‘parts’, with a brief inscription, ‘Humilitas exornat virtutibus virum iustum ’

‘Credenda’, aligning twelve prophets, a quotation from each, the twelve articles of the Creed, and the apostles; excepting the marginal note in rubric ‘Iste est ordo secundum sanctum thomam de veritatibus theologie libro 5 . capitulo 19. vel 20.’, the only text is the labels in the diagram. o
: ‘Fugienda’, illustrating the ‘parts’ of the seven deadly sins, with a brief inscription, ‘Superbia spoliat virtutibus virum ustum ’
: ‘Petenda’, a standard septenary aligning petitions of the Pater Noster, gifts of the Holy Spirit, the seven remedial virtues, and the deadly sin each extirpates, the only text being the labels.
: ‘Seruanda’, linking the ten plagues of Egypt, the denial of a commandment, the decalogue, a vice each command counteracts, and an action opposed to each commandment, the only text being the labels.

In addition, the MS includes a number of other diagrams: (a) the forty resting places of the Hebrews, under three arches supported by four green columns ; (b) a circular map of the Hebrews’ camp, with the tabernacle at the centre, based on Numbers ; (c) a map of Jerusalem, as rebuilt by Nehemiah, with intact walls and the six gates ; (d) the elements and spheres .
Other initia have 3-line alternating red and blue lombards on violet or red flourishing.
No rubrics filled, although boxed instructions for them appear regularly in the lower margins.
Alternate red and blue paraphs break up sentences.
At the head, a 5-line red and blue lombard on red flourishing and with a red and blue bar border.
Headings and the musical staves in red.

Stave-high red, blue, and green lombards or pen-work strap capitals at the heads of individual hymns, frequently unflourished, often on either red or text-ink flourishing. Verses of the hymns sometimes divided with 1-line alternate red and blue lombards, with the same variations in flourishing.
: three illustrations of the lion.

column8: : the Creation, in four cartoons: God creating the birds and beasts, God taking Eve from Adam’s side, the fall, and the expulsion.
Adam (confusingly in a gown of the same colours as the creator God on the facing page) naming the beasts.
At chapter incipits 3-line high similar letters, in gold leaf on blue, red, violet, or some combination.
Some decorative red and green line-fillers.

In addition, elaborate illumination: most chapters up to have an illustration of the animal subject, generally depicted on a gold ground, about ninety in all; many of these have English identifications in the margins, s. xv ex.

that the illustrations most resemble in their iconography James’s copy, corresponds to no textual or iconographic feature, although it is potentially useful in indicating artists who drew from life, rather than pattern-books. column8: In addition to the chapter illustrations, five full-page paintings survive:
: the ‘lapides igniferi’, a man and a woman attracted by their stones and then embracing in fire; at the page foot the medieval ex-libris, painted within two dragons and a tendril/interlace.
: the salamander tree, a dead (?sleeping) man under a tree filled with snakes poisoning the fruit.
No headings. At the head of the text, a 7-line high gold letter on blue and red grounds, with diapering and orange and white vine infills.

Other full-page illustrations, on the basis of the analogous Ashmole and CUL MSS, were on leaves now removed: two pages of illustrations of dogs, after ; eagles flying towards the sun, after ; the whale mistaken for an island, after ; and Isidore composing his book, after .
Headings in red.
In item 1, headings in red, alternate 1-line red and green arabesque capitals to divide the verses.
The only other decoration is 3-line red, blue, and green arabesque capitals at the heads of the sermons, with infill in a contrasting colour.
Running titles in red with book numbers (ending on at the end of the main series of letters).
Only books 13 and 14 have large decorated capitals, 4-line arabesque initials, the first with a marginal descender in red and blue, the second formed by a red and blue vine design.
At the heads of individual letters, 2-line alternating red and blue arabesque capitals on flourishing of the other colour.
At the head, , space for a 4-line capital unfilled.
Headings in red, some unfilled and some in rustic capitals (all those in quire 5, for example).
Running titles on rectos give the number of the psalm in roman numerals, in text ink, red-slashed; these were supplemented, , by arabic numbers on the versos. s. xvi
The incipits of individual psalms are usually in 2-line high decorative textura.
See AT, no. 829 (84).
The individual psalms are introduced by unflourished red lombards of the same size.
Red-slashed capitals at the heads of sentences; very occasional 1-line red lombards or red paraphs for the same purpose.
The names of authorities in red (to the end of quire 8 only, thereafter simply underlined in red), red underline for the biblical text and biblical cross-references.

At the head of the prologue, a 7-line blue lombard with descender, on red flourishing, which forms a lion within the letter; at the incipits of the nocturns, similar 4- or 8-line initials (usually leaf forms but two animal shapes in that on ).
At the head a 7-line champe in blue, violet, and gold leaf, with a leafy spray.
Decorative top-line ascenders are often filled with faces and various animal shapes (fish, lions’ heads, birds), frequently coloured with rubricator’s red.
Sermons broken with alternate red and blue paraphs and red-slashed capitals; red underlining for biblical citations.
Headings in red, introduced by 1-line unflourished blue lombards.
The sermons are introduced by 3-line blue lombards on red flourishing.
See , dating . AT, no. 318 (32) s. xiv 3/4
Sentences separated by alternate red and blue paraphs, also used at the head of marginal indications of contents in the scribal hand.
At the head, a 9-line high red and blue lombard with flourishing and vine and leaf patterns in the same colours.
Blanks for headings unfilled.
Chapters begin with 2- and 3-line alternating red and blue lombards on flourishing of the other colour.
Alternate red and green 1-line rustic capitals to introduce items in the table of chapters.
Headings and roman chapter numbers in red (the latter added later?).
At the head, a 6-line high green arabesque capital with red flourishing. At chapter openings, 2-line alternating red and green arabesque capitals with flourishing of the other colour.
Headings in red, 2-line champes at chapter heads.

On an illumination, two doctors consulting in a columned portico, with a full vine and leaf border, primarily in blue and gold, with strawberries, roses, etc., and a 4-line blue and violet champe capital with vine and leaf design on gold leaf.

, no. 811 (81), associate the book with 'the style of ' ( ) and plate liii ; they also cite his work from ; and (nos. 812 and 813, ibid.). AT Willem Vrelant Bruges Lincoln College, MS Lat. 149 Keble College MS 46
column40: AT; Lincoln College, MS Lat. 149; Keble College MS 46

column8: Text 2 introduced by a 4-line champe with bud sprays.
Contents tables preceding each book of item 1 introduced by 3-line champes; individual entries preceded by 1-line lombards, alternating gold on black flourishing and blue on red flourishing.
At chapter openings 3- and 4-line unflourished lombards in red.
Chapter titles and names of speakers in the dialogues in text ink underlined in red; red paraphs to break up sentences.
The text is broken with alternate red and blue paraphs.
The new text is introduced by a 9-line blue and gold leaf lombard on red and violet flourishing with red, blue, and gold leaf bar border.
The text is broken with frequent red paraphs, text capitals at sentence heads frequently ochre-slashed (as are also some catchwords).
The text is broken with alternate red and blue paraphs.
At the heads of chapters 2- and 3-line lombards in text ink, many simply in outline (capitals are unfilled in quires 4–5, on a unique paper stock and with a shift in page format).
At the head, a 15-line red lombard, with apparently an armorial (Greek cross with ermines).
Headings in red (although in the main unfilled).
At the start of the ‘visions’, 2-line arabesque capitals in red, green, and gold.
Widely dispersed red headings to set off the separate ‘visions’.
At and , 8-line arabesque capitals in blue with green and touches of red and in green with blue and gold respectively.
The text is divided by paraphs, alternating blue and red until , thereafter either red only or unfilled, and ochre-slashed capitals.
Book numbers added later in lead as running titles.

At initia, lombards, 10 lines at the head of the prologue, 4 lines at the heads of chapters, initially alternating red on black flourishing, blue on red flourishing (to , sporadic later examples of the blue), the flourishing including leaf designs and heads; after , capitals universally unflourished and after , none filled.
Headings in red and in a more formal humanistica.
Alternating red and blue paraphs to divide the text.
Red-slashed capitals at heads of sentences to divide the text.
In the original parts of Manuscript 1: headings in red.
In the original parts of Manuscript 2: headings and marginal notations of authorities in red.
At internal divisions, 3- and 4-line alternating red and blue lombards on flourishing of the other colour.
At the head, a 7-line red and blue lombard on red and blue flourishing.
Alternating red and blue 2-line lombards on flourishing of the other colour.
See , no. 307 (31) and plate xxii . AT
At initia, 2-line blue lombards on red flourishing; alternate red and blue paraphs to break up the text.
Running titles, ‘Liber’ and the appropriate number across the opening in blue and red.
Headings in text ink underlined in red.
Headings in red at the start, later left blank, sometimes supplied in text ink.
2- and 3-line blue lombards, unflourished, at the openings of texts.
Frequent ochre-slashed capitals to divide texts. Scattered ochre-painted pointing hands in the margins. Intermittent early modern annotation.

At the head ( ), a 10-line decorated capital in red and blue on a green ground, historiated: a tonsured Dominican looking up at God, depicted as an earthly king with a golden crown, a partly defaced blazon within the letter (see Provenance below); border of leaf and floral sprays in red, orange, blue, violet, and gold leaf (open at the page foot). Overlooked in AT.
Red 2-line lombards at the heads of the 98 numbered chapters; the moral readings are marked in the margin, sometimes with introductory red paraphs.
No headings. At chapter breaks 3-line red lombards on purple flourishing; red paraphs to divide the text. Decorated top-line ascenders with leaves and faces, ochre-slashed.
Red running titles indicate the biblical book.
Headings in red for books and chapter numbers.
At the head of each Gospel, a 5-line capital in red, blue, and violet on flourishing of the same with extended flourishing and bar to make a vinet.
At chapter heads, 2-line blue lombards on red flourishing.
Some ochre-slashed capitals to divide the text.
In the table for item 3, red ink text capitals and red paraphs.
In addition to items noted above, item 2 has several logic diagrams in red and text ink, and a figure of the academic disciplines in the same (fol. 24v).
But generally spaces for capitals at heads of texts and chapters are unfilled.
Generally speaking, an undecorated student notebook. Item 2 is introduced by large swag capitals with birds, animals, and monsters in the text ink.
Elsewhere rubrics unfilled.
An unflourished blue 3-line lombard at the head of item 1.
See AT, no. 814 (81) and plate liv (fols. 13v, 29v).
The same 2-line champes with floral sprays at major divisions.
graded programme of illustration.
At the top of the hierarchy are unified full openings, with borders on both pages and full-page illuminations on the versos, often single leaves blank on their rectos and inserted into the quires.
One-line lombards, alternate blue on red flourishing and gold on black to introduce individual prayers; red-slashed capitals within some texts, blue and gold leaf line-fillers.

Seven historiated initials occur at the head of the individual Offices of the Virgin; each depicts an event of the Passion, paralleling the nocturns of the Psalter, but here Jesus before Pilate precedes the buffeting (fols. 47, 50, preceding Prime and Tierce respectively). The Virgin holding her child, imposed on sun and moon, precedes the devotion to the joys of the Virgin (fol. 64).
Individual prayers introduced by 2-line alternate violet and blue champes with vine and flower infills and floral sprays in the margins.
Important subsidiary divisions are marked by single pages with borders and either full- or half-page (with some text material) illuminations.

The Passion subjects correspond to the historiated initials which introduce the Hours of the Virgin, with one minor transposition: David in the foreground pointing at his eye (‘Dominus illuminatio mea’) and looking to God in heaven while Jesus is betrayed in the background (fol. 148); David resisting demonic temptation and the buffeting (fol. 162v); David lecturing a fool and Jesus before Pilate (fol. 176); David praying naked in the waters and the way to Calvary (fol. 189v); David playing a range of bells with mallets and the crucifixion with Mary and John (fol. 206v); clergy with a choir-book and the deposition (fol. 222); Christ and the Father, holding an open book, between two trumpeting angels, with a dove, and the entombment (fol. 238v).

Finally, there are twenty-three historiated initials, all of six or seven lines, within blue or violet champes on gold leaf. Fifteen of these introduce the suffrages (text 3) with an image of saint and his or her emblem: the trinity, father holding son as with hovering dove; Michael triumphant over the devil in a garden; John the Baptist with a book and nimbed lamb; John the evangelist, with his sign, an eagle, writing; the assassination of Becket; George slaying the dragon, with a praying woman in the background; Christopher carrying the baby Jesus across a river; Antony before a hermit’s hut, with a bell and a boar; Roche with pilgrim staff and bag meeting an angel; Sebastian’s martyrdom; Anne holding on her lap the Virgin, who is holding baby Jesus on hers; Mary Magdalen outside an orchard holding a blue pot and receiving stigmata; Katherine holding an open book with wheel and sword; Margaret praying in the prison with a cat-like devil; Barbara by her tower. pietà
In item 4 and the remainder, an 8-line introductory capital like that for item 2.
In item 2, a 6-line initial capital, blue on violet and gold leaf, with vine and flower design.

These illustrations include: Christ as alpha and omega, in a deer-park standing on the orb of the earth (fol. 13v, introducing ‘the fifteen ooes’; for iconographic parallels, see Scott, 2:301); the Annunciation (fol. 29v, introducing the Hours proper and Matins); Christ in majesty and the damned being drawn to hell below the clouds of heaven (fol. 70v, the Psalms and litany); the raising of Lazarus, with black-hooded monks in the border (fol. 85v, the Office of the Dead); an aristocratic David with a harp kneeling outside a city while looking up to an angel holding three arrows, musicians in the border (fol. 125v, the Psalter).
The borders include leaves, flowers, and fruit, as well as birds and drolleries.
Headings in red throughout.

Similar illustrations mark the nocturns of the Psalter; these depict actions relevant to the Christian’s imitation of the Passion, as indicated by the relevant Psalm and the action of David in the illustration.

These include: a wayfaring Christian with bag (the incipit verse on a scroll by his head), above him angels raising souls in a bag to a judging God (fol. 105v, the Psalm of commendation); and Christ posed as if in Gethsemane (although depicted in a deer-park outside a beautiful city, the incipit verse in a scroll by his head, fol. 116v, the Psalms of the Passion).
Blanks for rubrics unfilled (many of the scribe’s directions survive in the lower margins).
Five-line blue lombards on red flourishing at the heads of the texts; 2- and 3-line similar capitals for chapters.
Book-numbers added in pencil as running titles.
Headings in red (at the start some unfilled).
Chapters broken by alternate red and blue paraphs.
Headings in red.
Seven-line red and blue lombards with flourishing in the same at the heads of books; alternate 2-line red and blue lombards on flourishing of the other colour for chapters.

Frequent illustrations, mainly marginal (on this tendency in medical MSS, see ): medical implements, plants, diseased bodies, modes of surgery; a full wind diagram on ; a table of moon signs on ; a zodiac man on ; surgical instruments on ; several diagrams of operations for ‘fistula’ ; cf. the illustration reproduced in (from ). At the heads of books and chapters alternating 2- to 4-line red and green arabesque capitals, usually unflourished; at the heads of books, some slightly more elaborate, in both colours, rarely blue with one of the contrasting colours.
At the heads of sections, alternate red and slatey blue 2-line arabesque capitals (the opening one, , 3-line and in green).
