Frequent red paraphs to break up the text, a few red- slashed capitals and red half-boxed words (mainly separating narration and moral).
An absolutely plain text; a two-line blank for an initial at the head.
At the head, a 3-line lombard with flourishing in the text ink.
Chapter numbers in the margin in text ink, with red half-boxes.
Two-line blanks for initials at the heads of each of the 51 chapters, a very few filled, unprofessionally; guide letters in both text ink and rubricator’s red.

There are thirty-seven surviving miniatures of an original set of forty-two. In items 1 and 3, each suffrage is allotted a quarter-page miniature, two to the page, side by side above the prayers. See on the wave of such introductory full-page sections in MSS s. xv in. A miniature to illustrate the Trinity has been cut out of fol. 1va, and a lost leaf following fol. 4 probably had four miniatures. Scott, 2:32 The survivors are: the Virgin as queen of heaven, with sceptre and holding a scroll with the Aue; the Annunciation with Mary and a dove; Jesus marked from his crucifixion emerging from the tomb; Anne holding the infant Virgin with a horn-book; Mary with three red roses holding the infant Jesus; Michael armed above the dragon; Peter holding a church and key; John the Baptist, in a skin, holding lamb and cross; John the Evangelist holding his eagle; James holding a staff; James the Less, in a similar posture; Andrew with his cross; Bartholomew holding a book and a knife; George spearing the dragon; Denis with a crosier and his decollated head; Cosmas and Damian with poor people and dogs (Scott, 2:364 identifies but a single English analogue, in BL, MS Egerton 2572); Vincent with a ladder and T-square; Giles with a crosier and a wounded doe tugging at his skirt; Martin with a crosier being blessed by a hand coming out of a cloud; Nicholas with a crosier and three naked women in a tub; Antony blessed by a hand coming out of a cloud, in grey and black hermit garb holding a book, with a pig at his feet; Alexis as a pilgrim with staff and scrip, holding a book; Germaine with a crosier blessing a kneeling congregation; Leonard holding a link of chain and a crosier; Paul holding a sword and a book; Katherine holding a sword beside her wheel; Margaret holding a sword and letting a sheep suckle at her breast, an incision all along her front, other sheep at her feet; Barbara holding a wool-carding comb by her tower; Mary Magdalene with an ointment jar; Winifred, with a red line on her neck, holding a sword and a book; Zitha with a gold band round her hair, a gold-coloured book at her belt and holding a bag; Apollonia with pincers and a book; Agnes naked in a fire with a descending dove; Ignatius with a crosier, a pair of lions pawing at him; Agatha with exposed bloody breasts and holding a knife and a book. The two remaining miniatures each take up half a page. On fol. 16v, John Lacy, in his barred anchorhold, watches the crucifixion (defaced) with Mary and John, a partly defaced scroll from his mouth (see Provenance below), beneath the picture ‘Anno domini MCCCCxx.’. The only known English analogue for a portrait of the limner is the one probably John Siferwas in BL, MS Harley 7026 (Scott, 2:62).On fol. 56v, across the page-foot, the Last Judgement, with the dead arising to trumpeting angels, and a hell-mouth at the right foot; the image of God in the centre defaced.

Minor decoration includes red rubrics, alternate 1-line lombards (gold leaf on violet flourishing and blue on red flourishing), alternating blue and gold leaf paraphs and line-fillers of the same. In the Middle English, some green-washed marginal pointing fingers.

At major textual divisions in booklets 2 and 3, at the head of ‘O intemerata’ and the litany of the Virgin (within text 12) and at the head of text 16, 3- to 5-line champes, some with painted floral centres, and full bar borders in blue and violet with floral clusters, twenty in all. Item 10 (fol. 101v) has a half-border with 3-line champe and arms (see Provenance) at the page foot. In booklets 5 and 6, 6-line champes with flower and leaf ornament and demivinets at chapter heads; on fol. 144va, the demivinet has not been completed, and the 13-line champe has neither gold nor internal painting. At subsidiary divisions and in booklet 1, 2- to 4-line champes with floral sprays. Calendar pages are headed by a champe, and all have demivinets in blue and violet with floral sprays. In the Office of the Dead, the musical settings are introduced by swag capitals in text ink with faces, some bird and animal forms, and plant designs in pink and green.
See and plate xxviii (fol. 5v); all major illuminations are reproduced on AT, no. 418 (42) Bodleian Library film roll 201G.

Like MS 76, the textual presentation is modelled on that of Bible MSS. Rubrics in red; alternate red and blue 2-line lombards at the heads of divisions (up to , elaborately flourished in the other colour forming a full column border; thereafter flourishing ceases).

In the Psalter, which provides the decorative standard for the whole, headings in red; individual psalms introduced by alternating 2-line lombards, gold leaf on purple flourishing and blue on red flourishing.
Larger psalter divisions are marked by champes with floral sprays (more colourful than English examples).
Verses divided by similar lombards, 1 line high.

There is one fully illuminated page, at the head of the Psalter (fol. 7): a full border of lacy foliage and flowers, with putti hunters (one certainly an angel with trumpet) and animals; a historiated initial with David and his harp; and two roundels, one unfilled, the second David beheading Goliath.

Six historiated initials with bar borders the height of the page in the style of fol. 7; these initials, all but the first and last lines high, alternate with the champes in marking divisions of the Psalter into nocturns: David with his harp (fol. 19, 8 lines); similarly (fol. 26v); fool with a watching angel (fol. 34); David calling from the waters (fol. 41v); David with his harp (fol. 51v); the enthroned Virgin and child with a kneeling suppliant in sackcloth (fol. 160, 9 lines).
These also appear at the head of the abbreviated Psalter (fol. 96v), of the Hours (fol. 104, etc.), and of the Offices for specific hours within the various sets.
After fol. 114, a floral column border typically accompanies such initials at major breaks.
Illustrations of cochlears and operations , and frequent marginal illustrations of diseases and operations.
A drawing of a castle and city ( , lower margin).
Thereafter, no red and blanks, usually with guide letters, for initial capitals.
See . AT, no. 542 (53)
From , running titles for subjects in text ink.

At the head of text 2 (fol. 33), an illumination covering half the page: Charles in the same setting but now leaning forward to take the book offered him by a kneeling Dominican author together with a 5-line champe and double demivinet with two wyverns.

Incipits elaborately decorated with paintings etc.: At the head of item 1 (fol. 1), an illumination covering one-third of the page: Charles V enthroned, reading the book on a stand which also holds an astronomical instrument, with a book chest with other volumes to the side, on a ground of gold-diapered red and blue with gold fleur-de-lis, together with a 6-line champe and bar vinet with floral sprays in gold leaf and blue. Laird and Fischer identify (27) here and at fol. 33 with one of the artists who painted a presented to Charles V in 1372, now . the illuminator Bible historiale The Hague, Rijksmuseum Meermanno-Westreenianum MS 10 B 23

column8: The Bestiary is illustrated to fol. 194v, with about ninety small pictures, typically set into the text area. The largest illumination occupies three-quarters of fol. 169v, with three cartoons to illustrate Canis. Other largish illuminations include another for Canis (fol. 170), Adam naming the animals (fol. 171v), and a dragon waiting under the tree ‘perindeus’ for doves to fall off into its mouth (fol. 185).
The main scribe portions only: headings within texts in red; colophons and incipits written in text ink in a larger, more decorative anglicana.
Some texts divided by red- or ochre-slashed capitals (the latter only in item 21) or red paraphs.
Numerous coloured diagrams in texts 1, 5, and 21.
Full illuminations include the zodiac man (fol. 142).

Fol. 1 has a full-page illumination: within a Lancastrian S collar, with the S’s in gold leaf, and attached to an inscription, ‘Salue Saluatore Spes Sol Sapiencia Splendor...’ with floral sprays, on a blue ground a shield noir, the five wounds gules and the four clous argent with the name ‘ihu’ or. The device is identified on banderoles as ‘Nomen saluatoris’ and the wounds described there as five different springs, e.g. ‘fons vite sempiterne’ for the wound in the side. Below, a distich ‘O qui cuncta regis mile fortissime uere│Collarium regis es dignum dignus habere’. ; she associates the floral sprays in the frontispiece, which she identifies as ‘added’, with ‘border artist B’ of the Lydgate MS , probably London work of 1516 x 1523. His hand appears again in our . Scott cites our MS as an example of the common use of the holy monogram in artistic contexts (1:76 n. 16) BL, MS Royal 18 D.ii MS 187

Illustrations: on , in ink, with green, brown, and flesh-coloured wash for highlights, under a canopy John holding a pen and a copy of his Gospel, with a cross-bearing angel leaning down towards him. , first identified this drawing as copied from (where it depicts Matthew), a Gospel book made at Lobbes and presented by Otto I to Athelstan, who is believed to have donated it to Christ Church, Canterbury. The last few texts have spaces for this treatment but are not filled.

At heads of the two texts of the MS, a 5-line champe with simple bar extensions and full floral demivinet on the other three sides of the page, in green, gold, blue, and pink (the first champe green, blue, and gold leaf).

Seven-line champes at initia, with full borders (some cut away). That at fol. 105 in light green and pink with minimal gold-work; that at fol. 129 12-line, with the opening word as part of the painting, and with a blazon worked into the gold, now illegible.
At chapter heads, 2-line alternate red and blue lombards with minimal touches in the other colour; the text broken with 1-line unflourished examples.
Logic diagram added, fol. 180.
Absolutely unfinished.
Headings in red.
Four- and 5-line arabesque capitals (larger at book initia, 8-line for book 1) in alternate red, slate blue, and green.
In the tables, 1-line initials in red and slate blue and some simple red line fillers.
Headings in red, consistent throughout, as are 2-and 3- line unflourished red lombards at the heads of texts.
One-line red lombards and red-slashed capitals to divide the texts.
Texts handled variously within sections: divided by red-slashed capitals, red paraphs, etc.

Two sets of running titles (one for each opening); the first, red arabic numerals to identify texts with the contents table entries; the second set in ink, some added later in scribal hands, provide titles.

Two-line alternate red and blue lombards on flourishing of the other colour at the heads of texts. Although many have been fully or partly cut away, the person who provided the capitals wrote counts of them by the quire on the foot of the last verso, e.g. ‘iiij littere’ (fol. 27v).
Headings in red.
Alternate red and blue paraphs, modestly flourished in the other colour, at the head of each sermon.
Incipits are underlined sermon themata; large blanks between texts, which might have been left for headings, are unfilled.
No decoration; a guide letter for a 2-line initial at the head of text 4, but the space is unfilled.
(Ps. 1): an 8-line initial with David harping on a chequered ground;
(Ps. 109): a 7-line initial with the two persons talking, each holding books, the holy spirit descending as a dove.
(Ps. 38): a 7-line initial with God looking down from heaven on David on a chequered ground;
See , dating and saying the calendar suggests , and plate xliii ( ). AT, no. 726 (72) s. xiv 2/4 French Flanders

Individual psalms have 2-line gold leaf lombards on red and blue flourishing (in quire 3 on green and red flourishing); the versals alternate 1-line gold leaf and blue lombards, on blue and red flourishing respectively.

Originally, historiated initials at the incipit (also a full vinet, with floral sprays, two birds along the leading edge and a lion at the foot, part of the floral extenders cut away) and the head of the nocturns (with floral demivinets). Five of these survive; the missing leaves after , , and were presumably removed for their illuminations:
(Ps. 26): a 6-line initial with God anointing David;
(Ps. 52): a 6-line initial with a fool with staff and stone watched by God from heaven;
In the calendar, KL for each month a champe; decorative geometric line-fillers in red, blue, and gold leaf.
Unfilled spaces for 6-and 4-line capitals on fols. 1, 25, 64v, as well as blank lines left for rubricated incipits.
Texts divided by alternate red and blue paraphs.

A number of diagrams: of the planetary spheres fol. 26, of the orbit of the sun fol. 59v, of lunar and solar eclipses fols. 62 and 63 (an unfinished diagram fol. 64), of the zodiac fol. 74v, others fols. 81, 88, and 96v.
Headings in red, most unfilled, as are many spaces for capitals and some areas reserved for diagrams.
Some 2-line blue lombards at chapter openings.
In text 8, most headings left blank but red sidenotes for finding topics; elsewhere headings in red.
In some texts, red-slashed capitals break the argument.
At internal divisions, the text is divided by 2-line blue lombards on extended red flourishing.
Headings and running titles with book and number in red.
At the head of text 9, a 5-line painted champe in blue, magenta, and gold leaf, with a green wash around (unfilled blank spaces at the heads of texts 10 and 11).
At the heads of books, 3-line blue lombards on red flourishing (4-line at the head of the text); 2-line alternate red and blue lombards, on flourishing of the other colour, at chapter divisions.
On only, extended alternate red and blue paraphs to divide the text; thereafter, only red-slashed capitals.
No headings. At the head, a 2-line blue lombard on red flourishing; spaces for others at the heads of the individual books blank, some later filled in crayon.
The text divided, a bit fitfully, with red-slashed capitals.
Comparable to the preceding MS, although the flourishing is often in a different style with rectilinear marginal extenders, rather than curved and floral ones.
Headings in red, a substantial number unfilled and some not filled as planned (cf. ).
There are several historiated initials:
No running titles in Psalms, and nocturns marked with champes.
, Job, 7-line: Job and a comforter.
, Nehemiah, 6-line: a crowned throned king addressing another man who is staring into a cup.
At the heads of books, champes in gold leaf, blue, and violet, with vine or floral and animal motifs and painted marginal extenders, often the full column.
At the heads of chapters, 2-line blue lombards on extended flourishing and bar-borders in red and blue; chapter numbers in alternate red and blue.
, Wisdom, 6-line: Wisdom enthroned addressing a knight.

, 7-line: Jerome writing the book and, at the centre of the foot of the page, a similar-sized painting of the crucifixion with Mary and John; both use a very silvery tint for skin and gold leaf haloes.
, Deuteronomy, 3-line: the horned Moses addressing two of the Hebrews.
, Proverbs, 7-line: king beating his son with a mallet.
Running titles identifying book in alternate red and blue lombards.
, the head of Genesis, full-column I: the seven days of creation.
Verses marked by red-slashed capitals.
See , dating , and plate xli . AT, no. 691 (68) s. xiii 3/4

, at the head of the fourth lection, ‘Quantas habeo iniquitates’: the same Jesus in a mandorla and Job, clothed in white, looking up to him in prayer. to another illumination of Job in , another MS produced for the Barons (see Provenance below). Scott calls attention (2:338) BodL, MS Douce 322
column40: Scott calls attention (2:338); BodL, MS Douce 322

column8: Verses set off with 1-line lombards, alternate blue on red flourishing and gold leaf on blue flourishing; plain blue and gold leaf line-fillers.
, half-page: the deposition, a bleeding Jesus entering the tomb, with cross and implements of the Passion in the background, with the floral painted champe and vinet.
See . AT, no. 763 (75) and plate xlvi
At major divisions, 4-line champes with floral painting (the last such initial within text occurs at ); at minor divisions, 2-line standard champes.
, half-page: two angels lifting the soul above the tomb in a blanket, with floral painted champe and vinet.
, at the head of the first lection, ‘Parce michi domine’ a 4-line historiated initial: Jesus appearing in a starry night-sky mandorla and a praying naked dead man arising from the tomb.

There are five illuminated leaves, ascribed to , at work in from mid-century. Our MS is noted in a catalogue of his work, the Fastolf Master’s connection with several Chaucerian and vernacular devotional books of the (see Provenance below). ‘the master of Sir John Fastolf' England J. J. G. Alexander, ‘A Lost Leaf from a Bodleian Book of Hours’, 8, v (1971), 248–51 at 251 and n. 6. Bodleian Library Record Scott indicates (2:337) London 1470s
column40: J. J. G. Alexander, ‘A Lost Leaf from a Bodleian Book of Hours’, 8, v (1971), 248–51 at 251 and n. 6.Bodleian Library Record; Scott indicates (2:337)

column8: , half-page: the funeral service, with the corpse, a gravedigger at work, and three clerics with service book; with a 4-line gold leaf and blue champe with painted flower infill and full vinet with bud and flower design. that this outdoor scene is distinctively French in style; English examples usually occur in church settings. Scott notes (2:310)
Item 1 has red paraphs for separate textual sections and underlining of important sections in text ink.
The ‘Orationes ualde deuote’ at the head of item 10 include headings and paraphs in red, and some 1-line red lombards.
Capitals generally unfilled.
At the heads of chapters, 3-line blue lombards with red flourishing.
Running titles introduced by red and blue paraphs indicate chapter number and subject.
Separate writs within chapters marked with alternate red and blue paraphs, with marginal finding notes introduced by a paraph of the other colour.
At the head of the text ( ), a 9-line champe in blue and violet on gold leaf, with painted vinet of flowers, leaves, and buds, pared by the binder.
At the head of the index, a 5-line champe with leaf and bud sprays to form a demivinet.

Fully illuminated pages at the head of each reign. Scott discusses the prolific London illuminators and border artists associated with a group of apparently mass-produced Statute MSS c.1470–86, of which this is but one example, at 2:319, 329, 345.
Running titles (preceded by red and blue paraphs) to identify the regnal year and monarch.
Chapters of the statutes are divided by blue paraphs, with the chapter number, headed by a red paraph, in the leading edge margin.
Headings in decorative textura.

Five-line champes, including some of a greenish tinge, with floral pattern and flower, leaf, and bud sprays at the head of each parliament. Leaf patterns but no green in Statutes of Edward IV, becoming a bit crude near the end; in the first part of Statutes of Henry VII, the champe hand of Edward IV returns, but part 2 of Henry VII in a different hand, using extensive gold leaf and often rather minimal blue/violet, with white-shaped leaf outlines. The border sprays here also appear to be by a different hand than earlier.
Alternating red and blue paraphs to separate topics and the subordinate entries.
Ker cites Hunt Exhib, fig. 74 (102; , fol. 290) and Scott’s discussion there. The illuminations include: Hatton 10
Five-line champes with floral sprays at the head of each alphabetical letter.
Fol. 156: a similar depiction of Henry VII, in a red robe, with royal arms (resembling the Richard III artists).

Fol. 86, a 12-line historiated initial: Edward IV enthroned between lords spiritual (on the left) and temporal, within a full vinet of leaves, vines, and flowers; at the page foot in the border the royal arms, England quartering France modern.
Fol. 143v: a similar depiction of Richard III, with royal arms (a different set of artists, for both the border and the miniature).
See AT, no. 621 (61), saying Harvard University Library, MS Richardson 40 ‘is closest in script and illumination’, and plate xxxvi (fol. 86).
Red slashed capitals to divide texts.
At the head of text 4 (fol. 8), a 9-line blue capital, with gold leaf worked in a floral design in red, with a penwork vinet in red and purple ink, with vine designs and animals (deer, rabbit).
A second level of initials at the heads of the nocturns and of Psalms 51 and 101: 5- to 8-line red lombards with some infilled designs.
Smaller 2- and 1-line red lombards, the first at heads of psalms/sections, the second to mark verses and heads of individual prayers.
Headings in red.

In addition, all the pages in the printed books have been bounded and ruled in red ink, and painted decorative initials (gold on red and/or blue) with alternate red and blue paraphs have been supplied in the printer’s blanks. The woodcuts in STC 5083 (Chaucer, ) have all been painted. Canterbury Tales
Two-line red and green lombards, with flourishing in the other colour, at the head of each entry.
Spaces left for capitals unfilled.

For the general absence of illustration in Troilus MSS, see . She believes the artist may be identical with that in (Middle English poetry and prose), a book which also belonged to (2:338). See , no. 820 (82) and plate lv (the Troilus illustration). See Kathleen L. Scott, (Oxford, 1980), 32–3 and fig. 19 (the Troilus illustration). column8: Headings, running titles (giving book number), and marginal notations of contents in red.

The volume includes illumination apart from the Lydgate: of STC 5094 (Chaucer, ) is lacking and has been replaced by a vellum leaf, with a full-page tinted drawing (listed among examples of the technique, ) of the lovers outside Troy, with Pandarus looking on. Troilus and Criseyde Scott, 1:75 n. 59
See (fol. 57). AT no. 494 (49) and plate xxix
Rather plain blue and gold-leaf line-fillers at the end of verses.
Psalms introduced by 2-line champes with sprays; verses divided by 1-line lombards, alternately blue on red flourishing and gold leaf on blue flourishing.
Fol. 106 (Ps. 109), a similar historiated initial: David enthroned with his harp, three men copying music into books.
Fol. 93 (Ps. 97), a 6-line historiated initial: two priests carrying the ark and David walking alongside with a hand organ.
Fol. 68 (Ps. 68), a historiated 8-line initial: Saul enthroned striking at David, in crown and dunce’s cap, with his harp, standing in the waters, on gold-leaf ground.

as directly imitative of the Bedford Psalter ( ) and the illuminator as sharing stylistic traits with the illustrator of a mid-century copy of Lydgate’s , (2:262). Our MS is one of the very few she surveys to illustrate Ps. 51 (2:379). Fol. 56 (Ps. 51), a half-page illustration: David enthroned gesturing at a fool playing with two pointed sticks or swords.

Some musical staves, introduced with swag capitals with penwork animals and heads, discussed at and illustrated in her figures 24–6 (fols. 11v, 51, 66v); . Scott, 1:37 figure 25 illustrates what may be the atelier’s identifying mark (see 1:65 n. 4)

column8: Fol. 31v (Ps. 26), a half-page illustration: crowned David in a wood prying open a lion’s mouth with a dog or fox skulking in the foreground.
Illuminations include: Fol. 8, a half-page illustration: David in a wood kneeling to God, who is nimbed in a dark blue robe and holding David’s crown and harp.
Fol. 57 (Ps. 52), a half-page illustration: three women (coloured as Faith, Hope, and Charity), emerging from a castle towards David brandishing Goliath’s head on a sword.

At the head of the Psalms, a half-page illumination, a 5-line champe in gold leaf, blue and violet with green leaves, and a full vinet in the same with sprays and flowers, with similar decoration for the nocturns.
Offset dominical (and other) letters, those for Sundays ‘A’ in red.
The names of the saints also in red.
New anthems for the same feast headed by swag capitals, ochre-slashed.

Large initials supplied at heads of the anthems by non-professional hands in inconsistent formats, typically a letter in a contrasting colour on a field (frequently peculiar colours like orange and green), crude floral infill on some examples.

Headings in red, the text divided by blue paraphs.

Nine 1-line lombards to introduce sections, usually purple on red flourishing, in a few cases the colours reversed; a 6-line space at the head of the Litany filled with a violet lombard.
Headings in red.
One-line red lombards at versals.
The individual glosses introduced by paraphs in the text ink; the text divided by larger capitals.

Divided into sections by alternate red and blue 2- to 4-line lombards, with flourishing in the other colour. These appear both set into the text and written in the intercolumnar space.

The roundel for Adam and Eve at the beginning, 60 mm in diameter, is blank, and so are smaller roundels for Noah, Christ, and Brutus. The only filled roundel is for Lucius, a pencil sketch of the head and shoulders of a king. Above the Adam and Eve roundel is a faint drawing of B.V.M., Child, and a kneeling man with scroll inscribed 'Plasmator mundi Baten miserere Iohanni'.

Paragraph markings and headings in red

There are many paraphs in the same two colours, the horizontal element extended over neighbouring words, and the same artist was responsible for the running headings that cross the opening and label the distinction, in the form ‘¶ D’ | III’. This is all Italian work.

There is much use of blue and red on all pages. Initials stand in the margins (the scribe’s guide letters remain visible) and are three-line lombards in one of the two colours with penwork flourishing in the other.

The major initial E is historiated with the Dominican author, seated, his right hand raised in a teaching posture and his left hand behind a book open in his lap. His hood half covers his tonsure. The initial is plain blue with white modelling, foliated in orange at the upper and lower terminals, and is boxed on a pale rose ground. Two nicely drawn wyverns hang from the inner corner and descend the length of the column. The upper wyvern is more finely detailed, with an expression of hungry mischief, and is coloured blue with rose breast and legs and red wings, all modelled in white; the lower wyvern, who is held around the head by the first’s tail, has a rose-coloured body and blue wings.
The scribe drew in brown ink a wash-coloured headband on f. 1r.
Each text unit begins with an ornamented initial letter drawn in red ink.
There is an ornamented headband drawn in red ink on f. 106v.
There is no ornament.
The scribe drew in brown and red ink a headband on f. 1r. There are ornamented rosettes in red ink, also by his hand, on ff. 1r and 140v.
There is no prominent decoration.
Empty space was left for a headpiece on f. 16r . Scribe A drew a coloured interlace headband on f. 14r. Scribe B drew in red ink headbands on ff. 132r, 155r, and 158r. supra
There are full-page miniatures on ff. 1v–2r, 3r, 4r, 5r, 6r, 7r, 8r, 9v, 10v–11r, 12r, and a gilded and painted headpiece on f. 13r.
The scribe drew in black ink a tailpiece at the end of the text on f. 132r.
The text on ff. 32r–34v, 86v, 88r, and 90v is illustrated with diagrammatic drawings.
There are also two drawings of hands added in the outer margins of ff. 120r and 121r.
There are painted headbands on ff. 105v and 169r. Scribe B drew in black and red ink an interlace headband on f. 225v.

column7: The ornament is outlined in the same brown and red inks that were used for the text, and painted in red, yellow, and blue.

column8: There are headbands on ff. 1r-v, 3v, 6v, 11r, 67r, and 105v.
Ornamented headpieces drawn in red ink on ff. 1r, 13r, 83r, and 155r.
The scribe drew in red and/or brown ink ornamented headbands on ff. 7r, 38v, 67v, 92r, 114r, 124v, 139v, and 148v.

In the lower right corner on fol. 95v (end of a quire) is a flourisher’s account listing the numbers of ‘indented and flourished’ letters, ‘flourished’ letters, and paraphs. Fragmentary writing in the same place at the end of another quire, fol. 143v.
Catchwords in frames with penwork decoration.
Rubrics in red ink.
5- to 9-line red and blue ‘puzzle’ initials with red and blue penwork decoration, and penwork ‘saw-tooth’ borders at the beginnings of books. Penwork occasionally includes anthropomorphic designs.
3- to 4-line blue initials with red penwork at the beginnings of chapters and prologues.
There are also bust-length portraits of the apostle Paul next to the text of two of his epistles (ff. 93r, 170v).
Some of these initials are zoomorphic (ff. 71v, 111r, 130r, 152r, 161v, 169r) or anthropomorphic (ff. 57r, 62v, 66v, 72r-v, etc.).
A full-length image of the evangelist Luke on f. 1v seems to be the work of a professional artist.

The remaining decoration is evidently by the scribe himself. The beginning of each preface and of each epistle is marked with a headpiece (ff. 1r, 73v, 92v) or a headband (ff. 2r, 50v, 51r, 55v, 56r, etc.), as well as with an illuminated initial letter (ff. 50v, 51r, 55v, 56r, etc.).
